It was so good that I had to order a second plate. I can't say no to foie..The kakuni (stewed pork belly) appetizer? Also awesome. Melt-in-your-mouth pork, with SO much flavor!My black cod with a ginger-soy reduction was great! It was flavorful, and the fish was nice and tender. However.. it's a very simple dish to make. Is it really worth the price tag? Then again, even Nobu's miso-glazed cod is also uber-easy to make, so I guess it's standard at these Japanese fusion restaurants.The sea bass was.. well.. not as good. The fish itself was amazing - a nice, thick slab of bass, super moist and flaky. However, the flavoring just paled in comparison to the cod, because it was a lot more subtle.Dessert - Tofu "hot and cold" - A tofu cheesecake, along with a tofu souffle. Both were amazing... If I could eat these every day, I could totally be a vegetarian. 'Nuff said.So why not 5 stars? Yea, the price tag. A lot of these dishes were very cheap to make... I don't know if it justifies the price. Also, really guys, do you have to charge $6 for a BOWL OF PLAIN WHITE RICE? Nothing says pretentious, overpriced restaurant more than that!

Great but no so extraordinary because I had high hopes of Morimoto actually cooking there, but according to his staff he was busy opening up a restaurant in Mexico. And also I had the tasting menu which came ungodly awfully slow, I was almost ready to leave. I could of had the same dishes at another place almost for 90% less of the cost and would of been happier. The bathrooms where awesome with the use of double mirrors given a cool special effect!It was for a birthday party, and I honestly felt bad they spent so much money for nothing out of the ordinary.If it were for a normal Japanese dinner I wouldn't come here because its just inflated pricing for SLOW service and alright food.

Expensive but delicious food and great service. I tried the 7-course Omaske for $125 before tips and taxes. As the first three courses were raw and I did not like raw food, the chef was able to accomodate and cook my food. The 7 course meal takes about  2 hours. As I had to make it to a show, the waiter was able to bring the food out in 1.5 hours. I was very impressed with the food and service. It filled me up. It is definitely worth a visit if you have extra cash.

My gf brought me here for my birthday and i cannot say enough nice things about it.Chef morimoto was actually there and so we ordered the $125 tasting menu that he prepares himself.  Each and every dish was delicious, but.... if you are not that big into seafood you might find less enjoyment in the dishes.  My favorite dishes were probably the surf and turf (lobster and australian steak) and chef's take on a salad which had this anchovy oil oil sauce that was to die for.The waiter was very nice, helpful, and knowledgeable on the menu.  The bathroom has those japanese toilets you always hear about with all the buttons which was fun to play with.  Think i sound silly?  Go try it for yourself hahaha.  The decor is very nice and the whole staff is extremely attentive.It's hard to find anything wrong with Morimoto's.  If you can brook the price you'll find an excellent experience.  Don't miss a chance to go... especially if Chef is there.oh yea... i forgot.  If you're into cocktails try the orange blossom.  It was awesome.

Morimoto is a beautiful restaurant with excellent service. We arrived 15 minutes before our reservation time but they kindly sat us anyways. Our waiter seemed happy to be at his job and came off as genuinely friendly. Our drinks were delicious. I especially enjoyed the "hydrangea" which was light and refreshing. We had a variety of sushi for dinner. Probably some of the best sushi I have ever had. Simple, but fresh and delicious. I loved the open and modern decor of the restaurant. The women's bathroom stalls were pretty cool, too.

Came here for my bday celebration as we heard such good reviews. Made reservations and was promptly seated.My bf and I decided to order the omakase for one and order a la carte with another appetizer and entree. This way we can get a full taste spectrum of the resturant. We ordered the spicy king crab and the duck duck duck.The spicy king crab was delicious!! alot of meat, but it was tad spicy for me. Duck duck duck was huge! came with half duck breast, duck egg and a duck sandwich with a crossant. The omakase was amazing as it allowed us to get a taste of everything. The main thing that stood out was the oyster with foi gras and uni. also the sushi was melt in your mouth goodness!Pricey but definitely well worth it for a special occassion.
Only reason I'm giving it 4 stars is because the staff is friendly.  Loved the gyoza and seared scallops appetizer but the sushi lunch sets were underwhelming.

I've always been a huge fan of Chef Morimoto so going here was like a dream come true. I ordered the duck duck duck and my b/f ordered the rib eye steak. My duck was warm, crisp and fresh. I loved how it came with 2 dipping sauces and a egg in the middle. It was a big portion and the croissant sandwich was fun. The only thing I would say is that I couldn't taste the foie gras. I'm not sure where they tried to incorporate it. I had a taste of the rib eye and it was amazing. Melt in your mouth juicy beef! I even got to try a piece of spicy king crab from a person sitting next to us and it was awesome! Soft, fresh and tangy from the sauce. The food and service was great but the bathroom was out of this world. Talk about fancy toilets!!!! Make a visit and you'll see what I mean.

I came in with a large party and the food and service were great.  The staff is well trained , knowledgable and very accommodating to allergies.  If you want high quality sushi and seafood, definitely worth a try.Some of their standout dishes were the line caught halibut, sea bass, ishi yaki buri bop.  I believe they have their own line of sakes that are the base of the sake menu and then you have other varieties but it's not a huge selection.  We ordered a few bottles from the Morimoto's line and it was not bad.A great dessert selection to round out the menu.  Mori-monkey bread  with banana chocolate chip ice cream, banana cream, spiced milk chocolate sauceAnd the Green tea and cherry blossom tiramisu  with green tea cremoso, sour cherry gelato, tempura cherry blossom leaf, mascarpone mousse were excellent...but tiramisu was my fav.

----- RIP OFF -----People who are writing good reviews about Morimoto have no idea of what good Japanese restaurants are.... I was born and raised in Tokyo so I know real Japanese food. This place is all about media/advertising and way too overpriced.Sure, the service was fantastic, waitresses are well-trained, and the restrant looked very fancy BUT that doesn't mean they serve good Japanese food.There are much better restaurants in East Village and Midtown East. If you have money and just want to experience an "Americanized-Fake-Japanese" food, okay, that's your choice but if you are looking for more true Japanese cuisine, do not waste your money here, go somewhere else that are much more reasonable and tasty! Trust me on this I know Japanese food (both in NYC and Japan).

My friends were in town for a NYC visit, and they wanted to get together to try a good restaurant.  We decided to go here last night, and I am so glad we did!!When you first walk in, the decor is absolutely spectacular!!  Beautiful, clean, spacious, the right amount of light.  We made reservations, and we were seated right away.  We felt a bit underdressed - my friends were in t-shirt and jeans.  But hey, nobody really seemed to mind or said anything; so that was cool.Our waiter was very polite, took the time to explain everything - gave suggestions - and patiently answered any questions we had, and very attentive.So, the food is the most important.  We had the famous Toro Tartare...WIN!!  I don't need to go into detail about it, since all the other reviewers have already explained this work of art.  Truly, it was magnificent!  We also ordered the Lamb Carpaccio appetizer, which was also very good, but the Toro Tartare just overshadowed it, of course.  For my meal, I ordered the Chirashi Sushi, and it was delicious!  It was strange, I had a hard time finishing the Chirashi - I struggled at half, but believe me, I can eat!!  Is it really that filling?  Or maybe it was from the pure satisfaction of the Toro Tartare?  Not sure.  My friends ordered sushi rolls, and they really loved it.Toro Tartare - $28, Lamb Carpaccio - $18, Chirashi - $32, sushi rolls ranged $6-12.Yes, it's pricey, but hey I was fully prepared for that.  So, I would only come here for special occasions, and I honestly believe it's worth it.I really hope to come back here, and next time, I'll save up for the $120 Omakase. :-)Besides the Toro Tartare, what is my next piece of advice?  Check out the bathroom!!  Yes, seriously!!  Beautiful decor, crazy work of art in the stall, and of course - the special toilet...no really, it's special!Morimoto, I am a fan! :-)

***This is my NY disclaimer. Being from TX, I was shell-shocked at the price of pretty much everything in NY. Unless the food was insanely cheap or insanely expensive, I didn't factor price into my review***So the apocryphal story goes that Atlanta pharmacist John Pemberton was trying to create a headache cure when, mixing chemicals haphazardly, he stumbled upon the formula for Coca-Cola. I mention it because most of the time, experimenting with known, well established ingredients fails miserably. But sometimes, just sometimes, it works.Morimoto is one of those times. This was the very first place we visited upon arriving in NY. It set the bar high. Had I reviewed it immediately afterwards, I would have given it five stars. Time (and eating at a multitude of other world-class restaurants) has a funny way of putting things into perspective though.The decor is upscale, neat, and functional. Save for a wall of back-lit glass bottles, it's surprisingly sparse. Overhead, there appears to be a draped cloth roof, though I suspect it's cleverly disguised corrugated metal. Oh, and check out the bathrooms. Aside from having an infinity mirror arrangement, the toilets also have remotes. Yes, seriously.The food was good, though overall the theme seemed to be "cleverly executed twists on traditional dishes." Does that count as culinary originality? You be the judge. We shared the toro tartare (Morimoto's signature dish) as an appetizer, the tuna was gorgeous and seemed to melt in your mouth. Eating it was unwieldy, as you're suppose to scrape the tuna with miniature ice-scrapers, then dip it into the piped sauces provided. Half the fun is in the inventive presentation, half the fun is laughing as your fellow diners try to eat it.I had a wagyu bento box, which I thought was reasonably priced (for NY) at $21. Everything in the box was top-notch, though nothing compelled me to come salivating back for more. The wagyu portion was a bit small at 3 or 4 slices. Though I appreciate the nod to Japanese authenticity (where beef protein is a small portion of the diet), the Texan in me demands.more.beef!Wifey ordered the angry chicken, another Morimoto stalwart. Again, perfectly cooked, flavorful yet slightly spicy. Honestly, perhaps the spice was a bit too subtle. Very good, but it lacked that "WOW" moment...which was pretty much the theme of the entire meal. Morimoto is worth a visit, and certainly worth the money, but much like watching Morimoto on Iron Chef, it never generates that jump-out-of-your-seat excitement that a few other restaurants in NY create.

Came here with my fiancee on a Saturday night. The restaurant is right next to Chelsea market. A bit hard to find in the dark - we had walked right into Chelsea market not realizing it is actually located outside the market behind a large draped japanese curtain. Modern - very CLEAN looking decor. But not too trendy like many of the meatpacking restaurants. We got a tad-bit snooty vibe from the front of house lady which almost ruined my experience because she snapped at us for being 7 min late (it was a rainy night and traffic was bad!). Thank goodness our actual waitress was such a sweet japanese lady, this salvaged my YELP review despite the snooty waitress giving us a shaft table in the corner because "you are so late we had to give up your table!". Of course we had to try the omakase tasting menu since other Yelpers had been raving about it. It was pretty spectacular - although I really wished the portions were slightly larger. I am completely aware the idea is to have an adventurous meal of tiny tasting portions...but I did leave feeling like I could have eaten a slice of pizza. The nice thing about Morimoto's omakase menu is that they give you a good variety so you don't feel like you're just eating sashimi and more sashimi. Each of the 8 dishes was unique and left me thinking "WOW this is new!" whenever our waitress served us a dish. A particular standout for me was the yellow tail. I wish I could describe to you the flavours that entered my mouth but all I can remember was how rich, smooth and heavenly that dish tasted. The surf and turf was pretty awesome end to the meal as well (and the largest of the tiny servings hooray!). Not to mention, they give you TWO desserts. A couple of Yelpers had highlighted that the bathrooms had Japanese-like toilets with all the funky gadgets - so i made it a point to make an intentional trip to the ladies' room just to check out the fuss. I did not see anything special. It was a regular clean toilet with just a cool automatic sliding door. Would I return? Probably yes - it's a good place to bring an out of town guest. But my tip for hungry foodies is that it wouldn't hurt to grab a cocktail and some pre-dinner bites before the meal so your stomach will leave fully satisfied! =)

Look, I'm going to be completely honest, as everyone else generally is on here.  You have to come to Morimoto's just to say you did. Now that that's out of the way, let's get into quality.  Like other food-goers on here, it's WAAAY over-hyped.  There is NOTHING memorable about eating here aside from a $247 tab for two.  I don't usually care about spending money at a unique restaurant, but this was a fail.  I'll never come here again, nor will I recommend it to anyone.  You can get the same quality at your local sushi joint for 1/10 of the price.Again, go here if you want to tell your friends you went here, or try it if you wanted to (like we did) but expect nothing great.Now that I've said this, hopefully you go in expecting garbage and have the best meal of your life :)

Excellent food, excellent drinks, excellent service. The toro tartare is outstanding and an absolute must. The Wagyu carpaccio is great, as is the unagi with foie gras. The oysters with foie gras were incredible. Great food and very reasonably priced, I'll be back for sure.

*update* I was told that there is no duck fried rice in the 'Duck duck duck' at this location..... so that takes the Duck duck duck out of the equation for me here... not enough substance without it imo.  Otherwise, typical Morimoto goodness.

Morimoto has been my favorite restaurant for the past several years, and I always make it an effort to eat here whenever I visit NY.  Salt encrusted sea bass, spicy chicken, and amazing surf and turf was what kept me coming back.Today, I decided to eat lunch here before my flight, and as I waited outside before the doors opened; the first troubling sight was the haphazard way the staff hung up the signature curtains covering the front entrance.  Dragging along the floor, stepping over it, and taking a smoke break when done hanging while leaving the ladder blocking the door; minor but it was just a sign of things to come.  I ordered the katsu don lunch set, and when it came out; it looked delicious as expected; covered in light layer of seaweed.  I started with the salad and pickled vegetables, and those were spot on.  The miso soup was just luke warm but hey, I hated always burning my tongue.  Then came the first bite of the pork, and I literally felt physically ill.  Mushy, way too salty, and just not appetizing at all.  I always finish my meal unless I think I'll die from food poisoning, and today was one of those food poisoning days.The bright side is my girlfriend loved her black cod even though it was again too salty, but it really is sad to see a restaurant I've recommended to anyone visiting NY end up in this state.

There's something to be said about a dining experience when the only thing you take a photo of is the restroom. Ok, ok, the food presentation is still quite beautiful but the flavors and the end result of the dishes I ordered left me feeling disappointed. Don't get me wrong, they weren't bad, but for the $ - it's really nothing special.

Love the restaurant!!!   Great service!"Iron chef" chicken noodle soup.  Amazing chicken broth, very chickeny, the chicken itself was a little bit dry, but the ramen was AMAZING!  I'm not a ramen person at all, but this noodle was semi transparent, super silky, bouncy, not chewy or too soft.Oyster foie gras w uni n teriyaki sauce.  Super rich n creamy.  You can taste both foie gras n the oyster.  Sautéed foie gras and grilled eel w sake meyer lemon drops, Asian pear, sansho pepper!  A extremely rich and fulfilling dish!  Foie gras was perfectly seared; the lemon drops were very light n rich in favor, touch spicy; the Asian pear added the perfect amount of crunchiness, very refreshing; that leave added just a touch of earthy taste.  The BEST foie gras dish!  The colors, different textures and different favors just worked amazing together!Amazingly fresh Chirashi bowl w perfectly cooked rice and awesome seasoning. The sushi rolls were pretty good in favor, but the look of them was not that attractive.
Great interior. I love the bottle wall and ceiling! Also, the black cod and milk chocolate cake are fantastic. I'll go there again in future!

Came for sushi. Good fish and well portioned. All just fine. Nothing special. Had rock shrimp appetizer of very good quality shrimp coated in flavorless goo. How do you make bland wasabi and gochujang sauce? Had vacherin for dessert. Oof, skip it. It's deconstructed all over the plate. It's a gloppy mess. I thought I was in for higher caliber culinary experience. Not tonight. Cocktails were good.Bigger issue for me was the space. It's looking rather tired. Fix the busted wall edges, paint the bathroom walls, refinish the bar top... Oh, and train your front of the house staff how to handle guests' checked coats. Getting an arm full of coats dumped in your arms in the scrum of people coming and going is just not cool.
visited this place during the new york restaurant week. loved the chic and modern decoration, but would not be my go-to place if i want some authentic Japanese food
I've been here several times and we keep coming back for an exceptional meal and dining experience

Yeahhhh...pure genius. Never had a bad experience here. Cocktails are perfect.  The sushi is rediculous. The chef prepared entrees will make you want to go to culinary school to learn how to make it for yourself everyday.

Had the omakase with family; food & service were very good. I gave 4 stars because I felt that omakase at Nobu was better... Could be blurred memory, but at least that was my feeling throughout dinner... Until desert came. The matcha dessert made the meal & totally redeemed Morimoto.

Had dinner for 5 this past Friday, hostess and staff were professional and servers were helpful and entertaining.  four stars for them.  I eat sushi about twice a month, but typically in NJ.  So dining on high-end sushi is not my norm.  Not that NJ doesn't have great sushi, but most are not in the $$$$ range.  I ordered the eel and foie gras and eel app which was quite good and the others had the rock shrimp, toro tuna, and some others.  The shrimp was a bit over cooked and tuna was good, but I prefer larger pieces than the chopped style.  My entree, charashi was bulging with fresh fish and other seafood, was well prepared with quality sushi and nicely seasoned rice.  My spouse had a seafood stew and a side of ramen noodles.  Though the flavor was good, it was much too salty (my wife usually adds salt to all her meals) and relatively overcooked.  Same for the ramen, really salty.  Overall a bit disappointed in the food which is the reason for an average review. Fish was good but not great.  With the base jun mai sake, expect to pay about $100 a person.

The interior can use a bit of updating. The toro tartare was slightly smaller than I expected, but definitely delicious. All of the sushi was fantastic (soft shell crab roll was my favorite). The matcha tirimasu was amazing and would come back for that. Overall a great meal.

Expect the price to be high. However, like many others have said, you're getting what you pay for.I had the gyoza, Japanese a5 appetizer, the chef's selection of seasonal sushi as well as a roll and the duck.Best duck I've ever had by far. Japanese a5 was extremely tender and presented wonderfully. All of the food in general was prepared to perfection. Receiving seating for two immediately as a walk in was surprising. The area in which we were seated was obviously for walk ins but that was to be expected. The decor was simple yet elegant and pleasing nonetheless.For those that want to have a modest snack or lunch, you could save yourself some money by ordering certain things on the menu which seemed to be more reasonably priced, but know that even the priciest items were well worth it.Wanted to go for several years, finally experienced and would go again.

It was just average, the sashimi was good but the overall experience didn't feel right.It was rushed although we waiting for a while with long periods of no service. It needs a refresh and it could shine again. The food was above average we ordered udon, sashimi, maki and a market vegetable. It was the right amounted food for a light dinner, maybe we should have sat at the sushi bar. Just 3 stars not bad, not great.

Beautiful restaurant but not a place I would go back to. Does not live up to its hype as the food is fairly mediocre. We had the tasting menu which was reasonably priced, but the sushi course was very sad looking, and the 'surf and turf' course was disappointing. The wagyu beef was chewy and over cooked and the lobster was mushy. There are a good number of great Japanese restaurants in NYC which stand the test of time better than this one, and which have waiters who are much less snobby and much more knowledgable than this.

Came here for my fiancé's bday. He's been wanting to try this place for so long. Definitely was not a disappointment. Atmosphere, food, drinks, and servers were all great.Drinks: I recommend white lily if u want a light cocktail with citrus flavor. Hydrangea (?) is delicious as well but this one has more alcohol to it. Sesame blossom was odd. Wasn't really my thing.Food; wagyu carpaccio: so good. Perfect balance between the sauce and the beef. Rock shrimp: I don't like wasabi but the sauce they made with wasabi was delicious. Shrimp was decent sized and perfectly crisp. Toto tartare: if you don't try this, there's no point in going to morimoto. Kakuni: braised pork dish that was melting in my mouth. Buribop: yellowtail was fresh and the rice dish reminded me of non spicy version bimbimbop. We had sushi platter 3 which was 30 pieces with 3 rolls. Quality and quantity I cannot complain about! Dessert was 7 min chocolate cake. I think dessert was ok. Wasn't anything to rave about or memorable. I would try something else next time.

Signiiiiificantly better than the one in Philly.  It is at least three times the size, and with a cooler ceiling.  This one will not disappoint!  My client and I came for late night food.  I had the Chirashi bowl.  What an incredible value?  It was a load of food and came with miso soup.  You are given 10-12 selections of fish all diced up and mixed in with caviar and toasted rice.  Everything mixed together was perfect.  The fish just melted in my mouth.  The selections of wine were not over the top, and very good.  We sat at the sushi bar and the chefs were fun.  Waitstaff were great too.

I made reservations for Thursday. My decision was between the new M Wells and  Morimoto. I chose the latter because the person I was treating lives 30 seconds from M Wells and loves anything Japanese inspired. (It was his birthday and he's only been in the country for a few months. I figured it'd be somewhere fun to take him.)Tuna pizza, divine. Rock shrimp tempura, my God. My cocktail was delish. He opted for sushi and sashimi, and while it was no different than any other great sushi place, that's my fault for letting him do it. The service was great, our waitress was so friendly and attentive.We sat next to a couple's table that was up against the wall. Out of the corner of my eye, I saw something crawling up the wall and I spilled my cocktail all over the woman next to me. (Sorry again!) The man sitting next to it grabbed it with his napkin and said, "I think I just got a free meal." I sort of agreed but not so much; two omakase dinners aren't gonna be given away for free. The manager came over, swept up my mess, and asked if I wanted another drink. I said no because I was a little miffed about the bug.Anyway, at the end of our meals, the guy showed the bug to the waitress, who freaked. She immediately got the manager who came over, grabbed the napkin, and took it away. He comes back, tells the table, I'm sorry, but it happens. It's not a roach, it's a stink bug, and it just happens. Would you like a round of drinks or a free dessert? (After they had tons of both.) He asked the same of our table but at that point, I was over it.What bothered me was the manager's very nonchalant attitude about the "stink bug".I know how the game works. I spent a few miserable years as a server in my undergrad years. The owner was a family member, so I know how freebies are handled. Pretend to be a tad sincere, raise your eyebrows, nod your head. Simple. The manager should have been more accommodating of the table next to mine. I understand WHY you'd offer things they've already had enough of, but it was just too obvious. They declined. And for that, I took that free cocktail even though I didn't want it.The worst part of it all is that I'd probably go back, for just the friggin appetizers because they were so amazing, although I'd have to be pretty desperate. One star off for the mediocre sushi (again, probably my fault for letting my guest choose) and one star off for the manager, who was super cute but meh.

My boyfriend surprised me on my birthday by taking me here. I've always wanted to go. We've walked by it several times, and are left with the mystery of what it's like inside. We walked in and were greeted by a very friendly hostess, who checked our coats. We were brought to our table, as the hostess walked away she wished me a "Happy Birthday." We had a view of the entire restaurant. I sat facing the sushi bar, where you can see most part of the kitchen. First off, my boyfriend and I have gone to tons and tons of sushi restaurants. Yet, we only have a handful that we keep on the roster. I guess we could be considered "sushi snobs."Our waitress came right over to us, asking which water we preferred. She was very nice, and totally patient, when we took a few minutes deciding what to drink. We each got a glass of wine. And started to plan out the food.This is what we ordered:Toro Tartare- Definitely must try if you come here! The presentation is awesome, and so vibrant. The toro is extremely fresh tasting, and the rows of add-on's make it fun to eat. I also was a big fan of whatever kind of sauce came with it.Bay Scallop Special- Not sure what they called this, it was one of the specials. We didn't realize that she had said bay scallops, which we usually don't like. However, these were delicious. They were in a brown butter sauce with shaved beet and carrot.  Decent portion, and enjoyable :)Green Salad- We asked to split this one, after the waitress informed us that it was huge. She was right, for $10 you get a very large salad. It was simple micro greens, with a tasty dressing.Salmon Avocado Roll: We got this as an appetizer along with an order of salmon sashimi. Seriously, the simplest roll but SO GOOD. The freshness of the salmon is unbelievable, the roll was plump and melt in your mouth. I want one right now just thinking about it.My boyfriend got the "Duck, Duck, Duck" which he generously let me sample each of the components. The duck sandwich was probably my favorite of them all. The sauces that came with it were really great and complimented the entree. The duck was perfectly cooked. I got the "Chef's Combination Sushi" it is 10 pieces of sushi and one roll. I told the waitress that I don't like eel and I lean more towards salmon and tuna. That was no problem at all. I had a selection of salmon, tuna, toro, fluke, etc. as well as an egg custard. I had never tried that before, and I loved it! The roll was spicy salmon (perfect!). I literally enjoyed every piece, nothing tasted off. I loved how they put a tiny amount of wasabi on each piece as well.By the way edamame is not on the menu, but they have it...we ordered it with our meals.When it came to dessert, they really did it up for my birthday. My boyfriend told them when he made the reservation. I ordered the flour less chocolate cake, and he got the bread pudding. Both were beautifully presented and the perfect ending to the PERFECT experience. They put a candle on my plate as well as chocolates that said "Happy Birthday."  I can't wait to return. Thank You Morimoto!

My heart stops thinking about this place. It's so beautiful. Modern architecture and decor in Chelsea. The presentation of food is impeccable. Some of my favorite photos of food are from my meal here and I take photos at almost every special restaurant. Yes, I'm that annoying girl. In fact, my photo ID photo on yelp now is a pic from Morimoto. I loved every dish and my seat and the rest of the decor including the bathroom. I can't wait to go back. There is now a location in Napa CA but I haven't tried yet. I give this place my 5 stars.

Coming here was one of the highlights of my NY trip!Yay:-Sashimi combination: We got the one to share for 6 people.  This came with an assortment of  fish and caviar.  I loved the different varieties and there was a sweet caviar that I really enjoyed.  I forgot the names of the types but this is definitely enough for everyone to share.-Foie gras with eel: I forgot what it was called but the eel was delicious! I hate when I can taste the bones in eel, but this was cooked perfectly! Everything about this dish was amazing.-Wagyu beef: Super tender!

The restaurant is beautiful. However the tables are very close. We are party of two and originally we were placed at a table with other parties sitting right next to us left and right ...tables less than 2 feet apart. I felt so claustrophobic. The host was accomodating when we requested for more privacy table.  We had the chef table menu and it is incredibly delicious . It consisted 8 courses meal and each dish was very very good...both presentation and flavor.  Also, the cocktail, White Lily was really really good ...low alcohol but very very fruity.
I ordered an omakase, expecting it to be the best combo of courses the restaurant could possibly presents, yet found it to be a diaster. REALLY DISAPPOINTED.

Non-Specialized Restaurant Week. People expect to experience something they normally can't during the Restaurant Weeks, whereas Morimoto was just serving the same, generic lunch bento that they have always had, which means these foods are always available anytime of the year and Restaurant Week has absolutely NO extra value. That's a foul play. Definitely NOT cool.

Tried the place since it had a good review.Food is okay. The ingredients are fresh i have to say, but they cannot make sushi well.Restaurant it self has a good vibe and the bar down stair is pretty nice too.I say too pricey for what they serve.Overall, I was really disappointed how they could not pull great foodwith the ingredients which they have.Conclusion:Overpriced restaurant with great vibe, but there are other michellen star rated restaurants which tastes much better at their price.Prob. will not go back.

With a glass of Prosecco to start, the Iron Chef Morimoto does nothing but please the palate from the opening bite.We started our night having the Tuna Pizza, and I have to say that this was my favorite dish of the entire night.We also ordered the Rock Shrimp and a pastramied yellow tail. All were excellent and if you like pastrami you need to try the yellowtail this way.Four our main courses my girlfriend ordered the Duck, Duck, Duck, which is a duck served three ways, as a sanwich, roasted, and egg. The desserts here were also amazing, we had the Apple Bread Pudding and a cheesecake souffle.The service here compliments the hard work of the kitchen and gives you the neat presentation that you expect while fine dining.  From the moment we entered the restaurant we felt our experience had a touch of class attached to it. I expected nothing less from a restaurant owned by an iron chef, but they exceeded my expectations.
Food is really good but don't expect to be served quickly .... Yet the restaurant is overstaffed. This is really disappointing!
Never disappointed with this place. Menu is seasonal with such great flavors and presentation. You must get the sea bass!!  This will be a go to restaurant each time I visit NYC

Been dying to come here for the longest time. Ambiance is great! Loved the decor. Nice bar downstairs to wait for friends to arrive. Food was great (but not amazing). I loved the bone marrow appetizer. My king salmon entree was okay. Nothing special about it at all. My friend's black cod dish was great. Portion was large. My other friend's duck dish was great. It came with 3 dipping sauces, one of which was a poached egg. The duck was juicy and not too fatty. The sandwich was a little too much though. Croissant was buttery and wonderful but there was just too much meat in it. Prices were reasonable too. Why not 5 stars then? Service. Waitress completely ignored out table. No one came to take orders or pick up the check for at least 15 minutes. In fact, I had to give it to a busser because she literally never came around.

The food was great. I have already started saving for my next visit. It is truly an adventure for your mouth. The wait staff was help full, took their time when explaining the menu, and was over all cheer full (but not in that cheese way).

Mixed feelings.  I took my boyfriend here for a celebration and thought it would be a perfect spot for the sushi lover that he is.  Oh boy was I wrong! We started out with the tuna toro. This was at best an interesting presentation that went wayyyyyy to far.  While it was kind of fun to eat that was the case before the flavors hit out tongues.  Fun because there was ice cold fish that you pick up with small shovels and add a variety of crunchy elements to was a fun adventure. Less fun was the actual flavors. Fish was very fresh but chopped up and The weird thing is that many of those crunchy elements tasted like tiny fish cereal.For the meal I ordered the ishi yaki buri bop which was by far the highlight of our meal and my boyfriend had an assortment of sushi. The sushi had so many seeds on the outside of the roll, it might as well had been an everything bagel.  I mean come on Iron Chef we would like to taste the fish in our sushi please, especially with how fresh we assumed it was.Back to the ishi yaki buri bop which on its own would be the only reason for us to go back. They cooked and prepared this yellowtail dish at the table which was perfectly cooked and seasoned.  A must have if you decide to go.Also the bathrooms are pretty cool but you have to go to understand.

It's a nice place for a date, as the decor is quite trendy and modern. The noise level is fairly low so I'd imagine every table can have their own engaging conversations.The food, however, was not phenomenal like some other heavy-hitter restaurants on the west side. It's probably not fair of me to expect Masaharu Morimoto himself to be preparing my dinner, but I didn't find the meal to be that special. The toro tartare and wagyu beef carpaccio are quite good, but they would end up being the highlight of your meal. The yosedofu is a great for the table, because they bring a pot to your table and prepare fresh tofu right in front of you as you wait for ten minutes.The braised black cod is a nice dinner option, and so is the duck, duck, duck. I personally enjoyed the surf & turf, which is wagyu with hamachi. The meats are prepared pretty well, and I do enjoy the complements to each dish as well.For the price range, though, there are some better options in the area, and certainly in New York. For example Buddakan just next door is quite a bit cheaper and offers some interesting fusion dishes. Nonetheless, Morimoto is definitely worth a visit if you live in New York and have yet to try it. I do hear the one in Philadelphia is better, though.

First off, Morimoto gave me one of the best celebrity sightings I've had, Peter Dinklage was leaving the restaurant just as I was arriving, so that set the night off right to begin with, but even if I didn't run into one of my favorite actors, Morimoto's food was a celebrity sighting unto itself. The plates we had were so inventive and different from anything I'd had before that I felt like I was at the table on Iron Chef.  Add to that the swank interior that was large, but not cavernous, and you get yourself 5 stars Morimoto.

Morimoto was just okay. I had high expectations for this establishment. I had the Ramen and tried various sushi and sashimi pieces. I found most things I tried to be extremely salty.  The sushi/sashimi pieces were just okay. I guess I do have high expectations, especially for this price point. I mean I know it isn't Masa, but still I should of been more excited. Dont think I'll be back anytime soon.
Go for the ambiance stay for the tartar :-)

I have mixed feelings about this restaurant. The food is pretty good, and the atmosphere is very "chic" but I often feel like the food quality is 1) increasingly inconsistent and 2) is very expensive and overpriced for the quality. There was a time when I would have thought that the food was high enough quality that is was worth the high cost - but recently I've gone in several times and experienced poor service and a mixture of delicious and mediocre food.If this restaurant were less expensive, I would be giving it a 5-star rating. But when we're talking food that is on average $20 per appetizer, I expect better for EVERY dish that comes to the table and not just some of them.I think I'll skip this place for a while. Maybe they're just going through some kind of slump.

5 GREAT REASONS TO VISIT MORIMOTO:1. It's the celebrity Iron Chef's namesake restaurant in NYC. 'Nuff said.2. The Morimoto omakase. Subtle and delicate at times and creative and complex at others, the omakase will charm you, thrill you, and pamper you from delectable beginning (toro tartare) to sweet end (tofu cheesecake).3. The Oyster Foie Gras.Ok, I know I already listed the food as #2 but the Oyster Foie Gras is worth mentioning as its own reason. Oh Morimoto, you sir, are a genius. Steamed oyster + foie gras + uni = one amazingly perfect bite! yelp.com/biz_photos/t1w4…4. The eye candy. The omakase is a feast for the eyes as much as it is a feast for the tummy. The presentation of each course was gorgeous, like little works of art to match the sleek and modern interior of the restaurant. yelp.com/biz_photos/t1w4…5. The bathroom. O M G, the bathroom! Let the fancy schmancy Japanese toilet beckon you into a stall with its sensor lid. Settle down on the warmed seat, take your time, and don't pass up on the chance to experiment with the button panel. But I have to say, as cool as the toilets are, what I really love about the bathroom is this: yelp.com/biz_photos/t1w4… Zen.*My only disappointment was that Morimoto wasn't in the house. I would have liked to meet him. Perhaps next time...

To be honest, I wasn't totally enthusiastic about going to another Japanese restaurant. But after giong there, wow Morimoto, you've exeeded my expectations! I expected oh you know... just another Japanese restaurant. Just overpriced =XThe oyster foie gras = heaven melting in my mouth. Moist, tender & juicy.The tempura calamari salad was pretty good. The pieces of calamari were large & juicy. Although the outside was crunchy, it was a soft crunchy... I wasn't used to that type of tempura but the different texture was still pretty good. I have to figure out what's in their seasoning!Seafood 'toban yaki' was a little bit too overcooked for my taste but then again I think it's because the seafood was sitting in a steamed broth until the moment I ate it.My boyfriend ordered the duck. & let me tell you, the duck is AMAZING. the skin was crisp, not dry & the meat was tenderly cooked to perfection. A must get if you like meat :) Great twist on the typical Peking duck.As for dessert? I was in love w/ the tofu 'hot & cold'. There's just so many different textures & flavors for soy... The dessert was light, yet so rich in flavor. My boyfriend got the strawberry cheesecake.I was impressed w/ the presentation of all the dishes as well.I love the decor of this place. It's just so fresh! Place is great for a date or groups & also great for drinks. If you're coming here, dress to impress ;)

I visited Morimoto twice.  It was a couple years apart between the visits.  Like most it was a birthday celebration.  Food, drinks, service, ambience was top notch.  It was an experience.  After $550 dinner bill (2 of us with tasting menu and wine flight), I would hope everything is perfect. One little detail the second time that left me disappointed: the menu was the same in both visits?!  I know everything was great, but please update the menu, so it gives me a reason to come to try something new.  Afterall, most of us came to know this man as the ultimate Iron Chef-- isn't Iron Chef famous for creating his cooking on the fly?  Give me a reason to revisit again.

For the price and the name, I was expecting the food to be a lot better than it was. I've had better sushi at places for half the price and twice the serving size. Overall pretty disappointed since everything we had here was just average, not even good. Service was not that good, either. Would not dine here again.

I came with high expectation and I did not leave dissapointed. This place is great! The decor, the ambiance, the food, everything was just great. The downstairs bartender was awesome!!! The meal was pricey but then again you don't go to Morimoto thinking you're going to have a cheap meal. Try the cheff's choice, outstanding!Iron Chef Morimoto came to our table to see how everything was, amazing!

I was a fan of Iron Chef ever since.... I don't know when. I was so excited to have the chance to visit Iron Chef Morimoto's restaurant when I was in NYC.The restaurant was very trendy and the decoration & the lighting were absolutely ravishing. A special mention to the restroom - sakura themed + great use of mirror, lighting and color = like a piece of installation artwork you see in MoMA.We had the seven course tasting menu (aka "Omakase"), and we thoroughly enjoyed every course of the meal. Each course was prepared with freshest ingredient, very flavorful and very pleasing to the eyes. Our favorites are Fluke Carpaccio with Vinaigrette Dressing and Mushroom, Vegetable Medley with Anchovies White Soy Sauce and Oyster with Uni and Foei Gras. Our least favorite was the Sushi - It was pretty average, both the ingredient and the way of preparation were pretty ordinary. Just not something you would have expect from a world-renown Iron Chef I guess. Only one thing we didn't like about the restaurant was the portion of food - either we had really big appetite or the portion was simply tooooooooo small. My husband was able to feed himself a big hot dog after the meal :(

Gorgeous restaurant and amazing fresh fish! The place had a great atmosphere and the bar downstairs seems like a GREAT place to get a few drinks with friends. all the appetizers i ordered were AMAZING! I had the cod for entree which i highly recommend

My wife and I had an excellent dinner and experience there last night. We sat side by side at the bar and were able to watch the sushi chefs prepare the meals.   Would definitely go back again.  It certainly wasn't cheap but it was absolutely worth it.

Beautiful venue and decor was gorgeous. You can tell that the food was going to be delicious by the number of sushi chefs standing behind the sushi bar and they were all Japanese :) And it was! I ordered the Omakase and although it was excellent, I still loved Morimotos in Napa a tad more. A must visit  for any foodie :)

This place was a fabulous New York experience.  The food was delicious with a beautiful presentation.  We went on a Sunday and got the 25.00 Bento Box.  Don't forget to use the restroom while you are there.  Ladies this place was indeed a "rest".

I am basing the 3 stars on the dessert and the wait staff otherwise I would give it a 2. I was very disappointed.  We started with the sushi platter, the smaller one. I had two pieces and had to stop. They should warn people that they put wasabi between the fish and rice. They drown out the taste of the sushi doing that and I cannot do that much heat. Blah! I was even disappointed with the dinner itself. I got the sea bass and it was drowning in oil, so much so that I had to scrape it off my fish with a fork. Icky! The eggplant that my fish sat on was soggy and gross. It tasted like it came out of a jar. The hubby got the black cod and that was definitely better than mine. At least it was not drowning in oil. The desserts were terrific. We got the cheesecake and it was light and the flavor in the ice cream was fantastic! We also had the apple bread pudding with brown butter ice cream and that too was full of flavor and very tasty!  Our waiter was phenomenal but that is not enough to make us ever go back.

great decor and ambiance.creative food -- faves were miso bone marrow w/chimichurri and salmon roe on toasted sourdough bread. solid.rice bowl w/foie gras, eel and avocado were better in concept than in execution. needed a refreshing element to cut through some of the heaviness (albeit good heaviness) coming fm the other ingredients. i cld tell the ingredients were first rate but in the end, the rice bowl didn't do it for me. guess my expectations were high due to the iron chef moniker.full review w/pix on my site.

Beautiful restaurant with beautiful food. For appetizers, Beef wagyu carpaccio and fresh buffalo mozzarella were both amazingly delicious.   Mozzarella was definitely a pleasant surprise, I did not expect to have the tastiest little mozzarella balls here.   Tuna pizza was good but not mind blowing.  Rock shrimp was but heavily battered and too filling for an appetizer.  If I come back I'd skip to save room for the sushi and fish entrees.   For entrees, the sea bass was biggest stand out.  It just melts in your mouth.  Amazing.   Someone at my table said "wow" outloud after having a bite. Cod was also very good - probably the best miso cod I've had.The sushi was delicious and fresh.  Every single piece.   I think we got the chef combination so I'm not sure what was included.   I do remember trying the uni -  I've had uni before at other restaurants and hated it.  I tried it here and actually enjoyed it.   We kept getting more orders of spicy yellowtail and spicy salmon rolls.  We were all full but yet there was always room for one more roll...Cocktails were also very good - the white orchid was a little sweet, but the orange blossom was delicious and refreshing.  There was another one with crushed ice and muddled blackberries that was really good but I can't recall the name.All in all, Morimoto lives up to the hype.  I'd love to be back soon to have the sea bass again and try other dishes (looking at you, oyster foie gras, duck, and toro tartare!)

Only restaurant I ever tipped 30%.Hands down the best Japanese restaurant I've visited among other chain of restaurants on manhattan. Servers were very professional. Very enjoyable experience.I am a very stingy youngster, but why not spend a couple hundred on a restaurant I loved the most during my summer? The only downside might be that the amount of food can be a bit small for the price you are paying

The staff was beyond attentive and the food was amazing my palette was in heaven so much thought in every dish!!! The atmosphere was great you can feel all the positive energy. Was worth the visit it was an experience.

Worth EVERY penny!!This Iron Chef does NOT disappoint!!First of all, the restaurant is this impressive work of art. It's like being inside a crystal cube. It is out of this world -from the high-tech bathroom downstairs to the glass fountain stairwell, my girl friends and I even had a photo opp with Morimoto himself.The servers were knowledgable and cultured.. not to mention gracious! Plus all the beautiful people (especially Asians, ahem hahaha!) in Manhattan seem to hang out here. Had the kobe carpaccio (superb!), kumamoto oysters foie gras (expensive for just 3 measly pieces), black cod, tempura (love the blue cheese dressing!!), unagi &foie gras... Oh, also had a long island for 13 bucks felt it was watered down. the hazelnut mousse was ok. Nevertheless, worth every penny! It was my second time and I'd definitely go back!

The only person allowed to be impressed with the toilets at Morimoto is Gene Belcher. Otherwise, shut up and be a real person (if you actually used it, then you'll never be invited to my house). The service was wack - and why wouldn't it be, I feel like I needed to have a disco ball shine over my head every time I needed the waiter's attention. The place is a club. It's a SUSHI CLUB, the dress code is "grown and sexy" interpreted by people who are neither. I don't dig this genre of restaurant, which does too many things at one time and can no longer be great at any one thing (not that anything was bad). The giant restaurant is for Morimoto fans more so than anything else. Obviously, I had to come here because I'm a label whore too. It's in the blood.

Great!!! It was an experience!!! Pricey, but what else can you expect. We did the Omakase and I am glad we did because I got to try some stuff I would normally never order!!! It was all delicious and fresh!!!

Review for Restaurant Week lunch. Best bento box I've ever had. I had the wagyu beef box, and he ordered the cod. Both were yummy. Beef was perfectly marinated and cooked, though it was a little awkward cutting it up in a bowl. The cod was tender and flavorful, and the sauce did not detract from the fish flavor.Salad was salad. Miso soup was well done, not too salty as miso soup can easily be. Tempura stuff was tasty, and the accompanying sauce was interesting. Sashimi and roll were fresh and delicious. I liked that he and I received different pieces with our boxes.We also ordered two pieces of hamachi, and it was pretty damn good.We had a choice of chocolate cake or panna cotta for dessert, and we both opted for the cake. Molten chocolate cake with orange sorbet. I'm not used to having dessert with lunch, but I'm glad it came with my meal! I nearly licked the plate clean.Service was OK. It was really busy because of RW.Definitely returning when I want to splurge a bit on lunch. I think they have the $25 bento box all the time and not only during RW?

Decided to take my GF here for our anniversary since she is a sushi lover. Its a nice upscale place. Ambiance is extremely loud but its fancy and pretty nice so i was excited hoping the food would match. We ordered a la carte as I know what we like and dont want to waste my appetite on other fillers.To me its unusual for each order of sashimi or sushi to be only 1 piece, so with the pricing of each order to be extremely pricey, i was hoping they were worth it, But they werent. For sushi we went with 4 x Oh Toro Sashimi ($18 each), 2 x Chu Toro Sashimi ($15 each), 4 x Salmon Sashimi ($5 each), 2 x Uni Sashimi ($12 each), 1 x Uni Sushi ($12), and a Spicy Salmon Maki ($8.25).Oh Toro for $18 each wasnt worth it at all. It was decent, not the best ive ever had, but just okay at best. I was hoping it would be similar to the best toro that i have had in asia, but it was far from it.Chu Toro for $15 each seemed like a waste too, if youre thinking about getting the Chu Toro, you might as well spend the extra $3 to get the Oh Toro. It seemed like it was just regular tuna, nothing special at all and way over priced.Salmon Sashimi was pretty good, pricey per piece, but worth it at a fancy restaurant like this. Uni for $12 each was different and the most expensive that ive ever had. they were small strips and they looked pretty neat. I was excited to try it, but then realized that i didnt like it at all. We eat Uni Sashimi about 3-4 times a week and after trying this we were definitely disappointed. It seemed like it would go well with rice so we made another order as a sushi. It was better with rice, but still disappointing overall.We ordered the Spicy Salmon Maki after we ate all the sashimi. I would have to say it was probably the best Spicy Salmon that ive ever had.After trying their Sushi/Sashimi and being disappointed overall, we decided to try other things on the menu. Went with the Market Oysters and were not disappointed. There were 6 of them and were prep'ed 3 different ways. Each one was a complete different flavor and they were all delicious.At this point the GF was getting full but i was still not satisfied. Looked thru the menu again and decided on the Surf and Turf ($39). It took forever to get and it looked very nice, however i was disappointed in how small the portion was. It was an interesting dish, tasted alright, but just very small like the size of an appetizer.Total was around $300 and it that was unsatisfying. i went and grabbed 2 slices of pizza afterwards and was finally happy. Its sad that a restaurant like this with such a great name can have such average and below average food. Oh, and service was pretty bad. Hostesses were great but everyone else, servers, food runners, and sushi chefs weren't polite, just seemed like they hated life, just didnt care, and wanted to go home.To sum it up, Over Rated, Over Priced, and Disappointing. If you want to go out to see scenery and nice ambiance then come here, but dont come for the food or the service, except the oysters and spicy salmon roll.

Totally worth the $$... Never been diasspointed any time I've been.. Huge fan of: Toro tartare, Spicy King crab legs, hallibut, their 10 hour braised pork with congee, and all of their desserts/drinks - the coconut drink with a splash of rum omg to die for!! and white lilies!!! Oh and tried baraccuda there... so all of the exotic stuff is a big plus for me.Servers are great esp the filipino looking guy (handsome and very great server - downstairs in lounge area)

One word: YES.EVERYTHING here is amazing... I don't think you can go wrong at Morimoto. Ambience is very sexy, great for a date or celebrating with friends.  Ladies: go to bathroom, unlike any other bathroom I've been. (I'll give you a clue... look for the buttons ) That's all!

OMGReallyHad the Omakase.  My friend has multiple severe food allergies, and the servers and chef were super nice and adjusted her omakase!!I loved everything.So many flavors I rarely get to taste.Now, I do feel like they tricked me a little bit into eating baby eel sushi (I asked what it was and got a fast mumbly answer)- but I won't hold it against them.  Those little suckers were delicious as well.Was $$$$, but well worth it!  Great experience!

This is one of my absolute favorite restaurants in NYC. I'll be in Manhattan next week for a photoshoot and you can bet that after a period of dieting and slimming down for the shoot you will find me at Morimotos that night enjoying my favorite dishes there: the rock shrimp and chicken soup. I know, the dishes sound too simple for such a venue and it's not even sushi (although I love sushi) but the rock shrimp is so light and delicious you don't even miss the sushi component from dinner. The chicken soup has an excellent broth and the noodles are handmade in-restaurant.I had the pleasure of meeting Iron Chef Masaharu Morimoto in 2010 at the South Beach Food & Wine Festival grand tasting in the Fontainebleau. I'm generally not one to get star-struck as I have worked with various athletes and celebrities but I have to admit that I was a little star-struck with Chef Morimoto. I told him how much I loved his NYC restaurant and he was so gracious, humble, and sweet. It made me appreciate his food even more. Go to Morimotos in the meatpacking district and enjoy your experience :)

Today, I traveling and just so happened to be in the area. I was craving for their tuna pizza and signature drink " white lily". I had my daughter with me and decided to seat at the sushi bar since they have a full menu at the bar. I ordered the tuna pizza , avocado cucumber roll and the chicken ramen soup. Loved it ! The dessert I ordered ; warm chocolate cake and the trio sherbet/sorbet .  Of all the times that I've dined here , the taste is always ON POINT! Thumbs up! My daughter loved the soup as well! At first, I must admit that I was reluctant in bringing her with me but the staff was very accommodating to my surprise!

Ok, honestly, I went here a longgg time ago (like over a year...I just joined Yelp ok?!) but I will never forget this meal as it was one of the best meals I've had in my life. Ever.As soon as you walk in, you know this is fine dining (Japanese style).  The restaurant is beautiful and white. Very modern.  We waited down at the bar for the rest of the group to arrive. The highlights I remember:-Appetizer Morimoto sashimi- they have toro, hamachi amongst other favorites plus sauces in these cute little eye droppers.  The fish is excellent and the eye droppers put a whole new spin on science class for me!-Foie gras- I didn't eat this but everyone else enjoyed itMy favorite was a hamachi entree we had.  I can't find the proper name of it but it was a very hot bowl with raw hamachi and rice.  The hamachi lined the bowl so that one side was cooked and one side raw.  Perfectly cooked. After this experience, hamachi is my favorite sashimi. I'll never forget the moment I put this in my mouth!Morimoto is so creative.  Everything looks as good as it tastes and vice versa.  The colors and plating is always perfect and you can see he really pays attention to every detail. He really re-invented modern Japanese cuisine for me that day.  This place is expensive-- keep that in mind! For the four of us, we spent about $400 WITHOUT drinks.  Ok, we ordered about 15 dishes...Next time I am in New York, I will definitely be back!

Came here for my wife and I's one year anniversary. Was looking for a nice romantic restaurant. I wouldn't say it's the most romantic due to noise level and modern design but that's my bad not theirs. We had reservations at 8:30 pm on a tuesday night. Place was packed and pretty noisy. Our waitress was great and very attentive even though she was quite busy. We had a bottle of wine and she never let our glasses become empty. I'm not a food critique so my details are lacking like some other reviews. But we ordered a variety of sushi rolls and a pork appetizer which were all seriously good. Its more on the traditional Japanese sushi and sashimi selections which I'm a fan of. You won't find a great deal of exotic rolls with names like "blue barbies pet dragon roll who had its wings clipped."  All in all we would definitely come back but not for a romantic night out. More for a nice fancy dinner and drinks with friends or just for what it is.

Amazing and swanky ambience. We had the Omakase tasting menu..shared it with my friend. $135 each would have been too pricy and too much food. We ordered half a dozen oysters and sashimi appetizer. Sooo good!!! The cocktails were delicious. Green tea tiramisu for dessert was heavenly!!!!

I love this place. I wouldn't call it your traditional Japanese sushi place, but it's really good. I went there a few times and both their seafood and steak have been great so far. Save room for dessert!

the iron chef's restaurant is pleasing to both the eye and mouth. the place is a mix of modern concrete and glass architecture and the food is exquisite!There is a lot of hype about the toro tartare but it is well deserved. everyone must try it at least once! Yes, it may seem expensive for the tiny bit of food you get, but, o.m.g, the tartare was melting in my mouth and the condiments made it harmonious bliss. Another dish I must rave about is the sea bass - the fish was cooked to smooth perfection. The accompanying sushi and black sesame panna cotta dessert with the bento box also made for a very delicious meal. I gave it 5 stars which is saying a lot because I'm a tough critic!

Amazing.  I put this restaurant in my top ten in the world.  I hope Houston gets one very soon! First things first, drinks on deck please! I ordered the Camelia which was a drink with saki and watermelon and was great.  The watermelon was light and refreshing, not overpowering.  My sister ordered the cherry blossom(seasonal drink) and it was delicious especially if you are a fan of whisky sours.  My mom ordered the hydrangea and it was quite refreshing.  Overall great drinks, but little alcohol in the drinks except maybe for the cherry blossom.We ordered the Crispy Rock Shrimp tempura, the Spicy King Crab, and the California Roll to start out our food experience and all of them were amazing.  I can't stop thinking about the Crispy Rock Shrimp Tempura!  Wow.  This is not what you expect to get with tempura, it is a million times better.  The shrimp has a light tempura and is covered in a light delicious sauce.  There are two flavors, I believe it was spicy something and wasabi.  The presentation mimics buffalo wings with ranch to dip and celery sticks. Each flavor gives a different tone and leaves your tongue yearning for the next one.  The Spicy King crab was perfectly cooked and perfectly flavored, it wasn't too buttery or greasy and it fell off the shell with a quick twist of your chopsticks.  The California roll was also delicious but the other two are things you must order. We almost wanted to do just appetizers because the appetizers were so amazing, but we knew the entrees must be just as special.  I ordered the Ishi Yaki Buri Bop, which was a take on the traditional Korean bibimbop but with yellow tail and a Japanese sauce.  It is cooked in front of you at your table in a hot ceramic bowl.  It was just amazing.  Bibimbop is my favorite Korean dish and this was a new way to love it.  I wanted to lick the bowl.I was told that dessert was necessary, no convincing needed here.  I ordered the cheesecake souffle.  OMG.  I wanted to eat more.  It was amazing, it was a light and airy cheesecake with red wine sorbet and green tea crumbles.  The red wine sorbet perfectly complimented the richness of the cheesecake.  The green tea crumbles were delicious and added to the cheesecake as well.  Wow, everyone needs this dessert in their life.  I will be back next time I land in a city with a Morimoto.  I highly recommend you experience this delicacy.

After eating at Morimoto, I am doomed from ever eating Bibimbap anywhere else.  The Wagyu Beef Bop is fantastic.  Our party of 8 all got a different entree and everyone enjoyed their meal.  It was a little pricey for lunch, about $60 per person, but we had a bottle of Champagne and Saki with our meal.  The decor here is clean/minimal.  The tables are group-style.  Our party of 8 shared a long table with another party of 6. Reservations definitely recommended.

I am back to writing reviews! Now that I have a regular life. I will update as much as possible.I was here on a date. Mind you, this may affect my review :)I have been to the one in Philly with my ex and we did the omakase there. The waiter there was exceptional and knew everything inside out. It was the first time I felt like he truly deserved every cent of the tip I gave him.At this place, my date and I sat at the bar. Which by the way should be the experience to go for if you want to see how they plate the dishes! :)I have about two cocktails here. The one with the blueberry and another one with orange and ginger. Both excellent choices except they are girly drinks.I got spoiled here. My date ordered tons of things in which I was shocked I was able to devour. Toro Tartare: OMG. It is different than the one in Philly in that it comes with an array of different things you can dip it into. There is wasabi (creamest and mildest version I've ever had), sour cream, mini crackers, chives etc. It came with a light soy base. I wish I can have this everyday :)2 pieces of the King Salmon sashimi and 2 baby octopus.. DELISH! Love their wasabi here btw.. so fresh!Whitefish Carpaccio: DIVINE!! I highly recommend this. It was so interesting. The dressing on it made each slice of fish melt down your throat. Words cannot describe the silky texture this has. I am so happy I got to try this :)Tuna Pizza: When It first came out, I was like eh.. looks so plain. How deceiving. It's awesome! I love the jalapenos twist and olives on it. It was drizzled with some white sauce which I couldn't decipher what it is but love the creamy texture!Tempura Calamari Salad: Eh. very fried and lacked in flavor. Aside from the argula greens.. it was not worth ordering a second time around.  Crispy Rock Shrimp Tempura: On the house for me apparently. Hm. Interesting. It wasn't really anything to rave about but looked pretty. I didn't find it memorable unfortunately other than the fact that it was crispy. $98 sushi boat: This is amazing. Everything was fresh and they have raw scallops which most places do not do because it is hard to keep it fresh for more than a few minutes. They are also generous with their slices and I love how I hate mackerel raw.. but this one was pleasant!Dessert: Cream cheese cake with fresh fruit and sorbet: This is amazing. Sorry. Keep using amazing because I am profound for words when I try these things.BTW. I would have given this 4 stars but the service and the decor is impeccable. I loved the whole layout and it was very romantic. Made my date awesome! Also helped that he was a gentleman :D
Words can't even express how good this place is. Everything is done with so much precision and knowledge. They use the freshest ingredients and it shows.

I have been here twice now and I'm in love. Something about the surf and turf makes my heart melt. The sushi is nothing short of amazing, I just wish it was cheaper. I would be frequenting this place a lot more if it was!

First time experience to try out star chef restaurant in NYC.  Took my cousin and her boy for dinner and it turned out to be an amazing dinning experience.We had:1) scallap sashimi (can't remember the name, but it is served with the foam on top)2) soft shell crab3) calamari salad4) eel and foie gras5) spicy salman maki6) Monkey bread pudding7) green tea tiramisuWe sat on the first floor near the corner and there was not much ambience at all.  It felt like they were some temporary tables.  We were there at 5:45pm and I felt we should have placed in a more pleasant area in my opinion.The waitress was attention but there was no personal touch.The food deserved a five stars though the service only a three.  That makes an average of four to my rating.
I LOVE the tasting. My client gave me gift certificates to Morimoto and my husband and I had a blast. Each course was great. Definitely would recommend for a date!

I wish Yelp allowed 4.5 reviews, this is a 4.5, not quite perfect but very good. Things we'd recommend - Rock shrimp tempura, tuna pizza, 10hour cooked pork, scallops ceviche was INSANE.... and you must have the duck duck duck, was my favorite thing on the menu. Staff we great and Paul the manager is a top man. So why not 5 stars? I'm not sure.... But highly recommend a visit to anyone
A great place to experience chef menu. We were celebrating a birthday in the restaurant having great dinner.
After coming here about 6 times, I think my opinion has gone from "great sushi at this price" to "overpriced OK sushi". Upstairs decor is very nice. Downstairs, not so much.

Simply an amazing dining experience. Absolutely great food and service whenever I go (which isn't often enough). Price is fair. Not cheap, but by manhattan standards a good value. The one thing that is also great is that when you are done eating, you a satisfied full. Not a bloated full and dragging!

Absolutely love this place - The eel and foie gras appetizer was amazing.  The service was a bit slow for a weeknight due to a few large parties, but the waiter apologized and made up for it in the end.
Tuna tartar, chicken ramen and tuna pizza.Stick with the tuna and don't order the ramen.

Long time viewer, first time taster of any food network star. I was lucky enough to stop by here to try the cuisine of iron chef Morimoto. The moment I set foot into this restaurant, I got an ambiance of fine dining. The decor was very modern and the lighting was dim with many illuminating pastel colored lights. A total transformation from it's outside appearance. I was immediately greeted and seated (for lunch) by the hostess and attended by our waiter. He let us know of their specialties, including the restaurant week specials and answered all of our questions regarding the menu. Top notch service.I ordered the braised black cod bento box for restaurant week and my cousin the wagyu beef bento box. The food came fairly quickly as it wasn't very crowded within the restaurant. The presentation was beautiful as the food came in a gorgeous bento box set. The food looks wonderful as you can see the attention to detail they had put in it. I felt bad I was going to jab my chopsticks into it, but my appetite helped me get over it. The bento box had 5 components: a salad, tempura veggies, miso soup, regular and maki sushi, and the main dish. The salad was alright. I'm not much of a salad person so my input may be inferior to most. It was lightly dressed if at all and had some crunchy scallion garnish on top. It gave a nice texture but I felt it lacked a little something. The tempura veggies were delicious. I ate half of it before I realized there was a cheese based sauce on the bottom of the bowl. The tempura was crunchy while the veggie itself was soft yet firm. The cheese sauce was light and did not overpower the tempura veggies. Greatness. The miso soup was good. The soup tasted as miso soup should be and didn't have me reaching for my water. The freshly made tofu was delicious as well. The sushi was excellent! So fresh! It had 3 spicy tuna maki rolls, 2 snapper nigiri sushi and a salmon sushi. The maki rolls were delicious. Spicy tuna, special sauce, some scallions, nori, rice, and sesame seeds. Very simple and it works wonderfully. They put the right amount of sauce in the roll to allow the flavor of the tuna to shine along with it. The nigiri sushi was amazing! I usually stay away from this and sashimi but man does Morimoto know what he's doing. The fish was extremely fresh. A little goes a long way in terms of soy sauce and wasabi. The salmon nigiri sushi in particular had me giggling like a school girl. There was wasabi placed between the salmon sashimi and rice. It was the perfect amount. Huge amount of tongue tingle with none of the nose burn. Ecstasy stimulating both taste and touch.Last but most definitely not the least, the braised black cod. Simply stunning. Slightly sweet and salty. The cod was succulent and moist. The flavor was outstanding. It was impossible for me to wolf it down. I took that fish apart piece by piece like it was the last piece of food left on earth. Heaven. I also tried some of my cousins wagyu beef. It was pretty chewy, and dare I say dry? The seasoning didn't wow me, didn't taste much different from any other beef from an asian restaurant. Good thing I got the cod! Sorry Morimoto. I also got a surprise desert! A panna cotta using green tea, honey, and coconut with fresh berries on top. What a way to end this meal! You can taste every component of the panna cotta and the berries give that much needed tang. Not too sweet. Just perfect. Great meal, great service, great times. Thanks chef Morimoto! Wish I coulda seen you in your element and not on a TV screen. PS. Check out the restroom. No restroom experience will beat the one I had here.

Eh.. what to say: The food is delicious but some things were off. 1. The bartenders who work at the bar downstairs are rude and inexperienced. They also managed to make the worst old fashioned I have literally ever tasted.  Our waiter at the table was super sweet though. 2. The decor is tacky, and this place kind of seems somewhere you come to be seen. The crowd was half tourists and half over-dressed poorly dressed girls getting ready to hit the meatpacking clubs.. Idk. 3. The tofu burrata was so strange. If you are a vegan craving cheese, maybe it's awesome. Otherwise, it's kind of bizarre to have toasted bread and fake cheese in a soy soup at a japanese restaurant.4. Get sake. 5. The fish is very fresh, have some sushi.6. Rock shrimp tempura is very tasty but I didn't deem it much tastier than rock shrimp at any regular sushi price.7. Beef carpaccio was delicious. 6/10
Devine and delicious!! Tasted multiple items on menu all of which were fabulous and fresh. We will be back soon!!Sweet genius winner is pastry chef at NYC!!  The desserts were amazing!

I came here with my parents and had a great time. The atmosphere is wonderful and the food is great too. You must get the rock shrimp as an appetizer and sea bass as main dish. Best sea bass I've ever had! Unfortunately I ordered the lobster which was the most expensive item on the menu and tasted like lobster I could get anywhere. That was the only disappointment. Everything else was great!

I had an amazing experience here, and it was worth the snow storm my date and I battled through to get here on a Saturday night. We started off with:Toro Tartare: This is a must get appetizer. It is so fresh and tasty and beautifully presentedOyster Foie Gras: This is also a must get. The flavors blended so well together and I thoroughly enjoyed every biteMorimoto Sashimi: Very fresh and good, but wish the portions were a little bigger. Expected for a high end restaurant rightMiso Soup: Really warmed us up from the freezing weather, but taste-wise nothing remarkableFor entree, we went with:Duck Duck Duck: The croissant with the duck was delicious and savory. I could eat it all the time. The dish came with two sauces, which I don't remember which was which, but one was too deep and rich for me.Braised Black Cod: As much as I liked the other entree, I prefer this dish. The fish was seasoned and cooked perfectly. It was wonderful.This restaurant is a must eat when in NYC. The interior is impeccable and chic. The ambience is relaxed and romantic for dates. Servers and hosts were friendly and attentive. I do wish there were more spaces between the tables, because they were almost uncomfortably close to each other.

Came here last year for my birthday here and 3 years ago for my anni. And Recently last month for my Girlfriends bday. FOOD is expensive for SUSHI. But, defn a good experience. The service is pretty excellent as is their Uni so fresh melts in your mouth , by far the best I have ever had. The entrees are so good Miso Glazed Bone Marrow was so delious. We had the oysters which was so Fresh it was so yummy. we had the oysters with uni on it wow it was amazing.

Overwhelmingly overpriced sushi.  I had sushi and miso soup.  Sushi was excellent.  The miso soup okay.  I wouldn't dine here again because of price, but more so the service turned me off. The service is nothing to shout about.  I wasn't impressed with the service but the food was a good comfort.

Been 6 times or so and have had very mixed experiences with both the food and service. Yes, the restaurant is beautiful (check out the bathrooms!) and yes, it's cool when Chef Morimoto makes the rounds and indulges his sycophants with a photo and conversation. BUT unless you're trying to impress an out-of-towner and thus, the scene is more important than the food, I wouldn't bother. The flavor is hit-and-miss, so if you've got the money, get the omakase since you're bound to get some dishes you'll enjoy. I wouldn't have bothered adding yet another review to Yelp but my last dining experience certainly warranted one. I've ordered the sushi here a number of times and it's always decent, but on my last visit the fish was old and something tasted off with the ikura (salmon roe eggs). Even more disturbing was the wasted, unattractive suit who was yelling belligerently at our waitress and was accompanied by what were undoubtedly Russian PROSTITUTES. Grateful for me and my dining companions normal, decent behavior, our waitress thanked us at the end of the meal by SHAKING OUR HANDS. I guess I appreciate the sentiment but I'm sorry, that totally crossed a line. Anyways, I guess you can expect such bizarreness in the meatpacking district (which I therefore avoid as much as possible) but if you want real Japanese food, there are SO many other amazing places to hit up in Manhattan.
