This place reeks of creativity without foregoing flavor.  I had the toro tartare and the crispy rock shrimp tempura and was not disappointed by either dish.  The toro tartare truly is a star dish.  It was presented in a thin clear window pane looking vessel standing in a bowl of crushed ice.  The bottom of the vessel held 6 different accompaniments to eat with the toro tartare that you were to scrape off with a mini snow shovel-looking utensil.  The quality was amazing and  the dish was visually appealing and appetite-quenching as well.  After I showed my bf the picture, he went back another day to try it himself.  I also wanted something a little heavier so I ordered the rock shrimp tempura.  It was served with celery and two creamy dipping sauces.  One was a gochujang (Korean spice red bean paste) cream sauce and the other was a wasabi cream sauce.  The gochujang sauce was great.  It had just enough heat to linger on the tongue.  I loved it to dip the celery as well.  The tempura shrimp were crispy and didn't taste greasy at all.  The two dishes together were such a satisfying snack.The only downfall to Morimoto was the sporadic service.  I sat downstairs at the bar (which was empty) and wasn't offered a menu until I was already halfway done with my beer.  I had told the bartender I was there to eat, but something must have gotten lost in translation when the other bartender came on.  There were a couple employees just speaking Portuguese behind the bar and it seemed as if I was nonexistent.  It wasn't until I spoke to the female bartender in Portuguese that she started actually attending to me.  She was great after that, but it sucks to wave someone down when you are the only client sitting there.  I would still eat there again because the food was delicious and the menu so intriguing.  I will just have to hope the service is more present the next time I drop in.

My husband and I decided to get the full experience and ordered the chef omakase for the each of us. The omakase consist of seven courses and costs $120 (per person). We also ordered a sushi and bone marrow appetizer. Although we appreciated the decent dishes skillfully prepared and graciously served, the portions and flavors were simply not enough. Maybe my husband and I are just piggies, but we both left hungry and unsatisfied.
Awesome food. apps were amazing. the entrees were amazing. dessert was divine. i would definitely go back again .. if I was willing to spend another $300 for a 2 person dinner.

Oh how I wanted to like this place, but it was just okay.  Yes, I see all the wonderful food photos on Yelp!, and I hope to return to Morimoto one day to try some different dishes and review it again.... but, until then, my 2-star rating stands.THE FOODOk, here's the deal. I went to Morimoto during Restaurant Week in NYC.  So, shouldn't the restaurant be trying to impress me during this time--that is, impress me enough so I'd want to return?  Well, Morimoto certainly failed the test here.  Me and 3 other guests ordered the featured Restaurant Week lunch Bento Box.  The presentation was excellent as I guessed it would be, but the serving size was only enough for a small child. I was displeased that I spent $24 and was still hungry.  You see, I work out about 2 hours a day and do a ton of walking, so it takes alot to fill me up.  I looked around at other tables of fellow diners who didn't order from the Restaurant Week menu and was appalled at what Morimoto was trying to pass off to me as "lunch"--every other table had huge portions of Japanese cuisine--while me and my guests were served 1 piece of meat-- yep, the beef Bento Box featured just 1 piece of teriyaki about the size of a 50 cent piece and about as thin as a credit card. Sure, they threw in a minimal salad composed of a few blandly seasoned greens, and a couple of pieces of a California roll (which tasted like just about any other California roll I've tried), and a couple of pieces of tempura vegetables... but, again, not nearly enough food to serve to a reasonably-sized adult. THE ATMOSPHEREMorimoto's interior is lovely, and the decor is modern and simple. I like how they have divided their dining room up so that the dining experience seems more intimate.THE FINAL VERDICTI guess the jury's still out for me. I was really burned during this last visit, so maybe if friends convince me to go back, I'll give it another try. Not sure if it's worth my time yet or not. I'll need to be persuaded.

This place is wonderful as it should be for a restaurant created by an Iron chef. I've eaten here twice and enjoyed both meals.The atmosphere is very modern and clean yet elegant in a simplistic way. They do a great job separating the restaurant into sections with glass to maintain the open layout feel while also keeping it private. Last time I went was restaurant week for lunch. The waiter was sweet and friendly. As far as food, we (bf and I) had the burger which was one of the best I've had (tied for #1 with the burger at muscle bar at Revel in AC). It also came with these awesome chips that were seasoned to perfection (of course made in house). We also ordered the wagyu steak with mushrooms and peppers. Unfortunately, this dish was lacking in depth of flavor.The desserts were the best part of the meal. YUMMMM.Side note: check out the bathroom! They're pretty cool.What knocked off the 5th star?1) Wagyu beef with peppers and mushrooms lacking flavor2) The hostess was a little on the snobby sideBonus: Location! It's right beside Chelsea Market and the Highline.

was lucky enough to be taken to this spot by my boss (yes he is a man but don't go there okay?! we were with some of my coworkers too) recently and was immediately blown away by the uber trend-o atmosphere. our gang of ten decided upon 200 bottles of wine and the tasting menu. as with any tasting menu, there were high and low points, but we all agreed the treats were really freakin' NaCl-y (that means salty for all you non chemistry nerds). i, however, ate four desserts because i've never met a green tea ice cream i didn't like. excellent service and cool space, but for the monies, you can most certainly have more authentic japanese food elsewhere in new yawk. ps - love you chef morimoto!

'Morimoto' is a place which does not need any more reviews. You can see the average rating over sooo many reviews here on Yelp and you can conclude its a great place!, but i write this review to acknowledge the great stuff I experienced there!From service, to food, to ambiance, everything was awesome! Among the starts of our order were the Toro Tartare ( a very unique dish), the maki rolls (which, though simple, but had a certain finnese about them at Morimoto), and the 'braised black cod' - I never knew a soy sauce reduction fish dish can be this good - you have to try it to believe it!!Over all, amazing!

Took my girlfriend to NYC for her birthday and came here as it was her pick as she claimed "it is the #1 sushi restaurant in the nation!"  Initially when we arrived they told us they didn't have our reservation.  Not a good way to start the birthday dinner...so we went to the bar and waited 30 minutes or so for a table to open up.  Then we get seated at a table in a side room against a wall with no view of the main dinning room. My girlfriend had the prix fix meal and I had the salmon.  Everything tasted great and was well presented.  I had the salmon which was also very good and probably one of the better salmons I have ever had.   The jalapeño cocktail was amazing.

We went here to celebrate my boyfriend's birthday and we have a lovely dinner experience. He had steak, and swears that the experience spoiled him for any other steaks :P The place is pricey but is worth every cent!

A luxurious designer experience. Ando Tadao, restaurant's designer has done an exceptional job of creating a dreamy, relaxing, private-public, sexy feel that is neither too energetic nor too sleepy. People here fill up the place looking glamorous, young, wealthy... or is it the atmosphere that puts a different lens on your perception? A great place to really impress a date!The omakase is a dazzling show. Morimoto can entertain for sure. All ingredients are unspeakably fresh and delicious, so kudos to the team for securing good supply. All courses are impeccably explained, and there's sufficient pace to keep your attention but also enjoy your company. Well executed timing. When the place gets busy, servers are more harried. A sort of rude awakening from an excellent meal once you get the bill from a server who secretly wishes to rush you out the door!

I came here to Morimoto to celebrate my birthday with my friend back in October. And let me tell you, this place is AMAZING! There's the main floor where the tables and the sushi bar is, and a downstairs where the bar/lounge is. Since I made reservations a little too late for a Friday at 7PM, there was only availability for downstairs. It was a nice cozy area downstairs. Very pretty place. We sat at a high table and there weren't many people downstairs so we had our privacy. And we took plenty of pictures.For drinks, we both ordered the lychee drink and that was amazing! I love getting lychee drinks wherever I go because I love lychee!For appetizer, we ordered the Rock Shrimp Tempura that comes with a a wasabi sauce and a sauce that reminds me of sweet & sour. So the two types of shrimp comes on two separate plates along with a side of ranch sauce. Both flavors were awesome. Ranch dressing drowns out the flavors a little so there's no need for it.As my entree, I ordered the Duck Duck Duck that comes with duck breast and duck leg and a duck egg. There was a sandwich to it. It all became very filling and I was stuffed! The duck was savoring and a little fatty of course considering it is duck after all.My friend got the lobster. She said it was good as well.For dessert, we ordered the Warm Flourless Chocolate Cake that came with caramel popcorn, and sorbet. The cake was very rich in chocolate. That's not really my thing. But the sorbet was really good.In total, the bill came out to $160 with tax and tip, so about $80 a person. It is a pricey place, but definitely worth it since the food is amazing!And of course to end the night, we had to check out the bathroom in the lounge area like everyone said! The bathroom was very pretty with the layers of mirrors and flowers/leaves hanging in them. The toilet was the style of toilet they have in Japan where you can have water sprayed on your butt to clean it...lol. Never had the courage to experience that in Japan or here, but if you're brave enough, go for it! :)Also, Morimoto is right under the High Line Park so it was a nice night to take a walk and to let all the food digest because we were definitely full afterwards!

Went to morimoto with a large group and we sampled bunch of different appetizers, sushi, entrees and desserts.  The seated wagyu beef on the stone was excellent and the table side tofu was the best I have ever had.  For dinner I enjoyed the steamed halibut that was cooked perfectly, and finally enjoyed the banana cream puffs for dessert.  Waitstaff was outstanding as usual and everyone enjoyed food.  Photos on my Instagram @cheflacsto

I'm still so overwhelmed by Morimoto that I don't really know how to structure this review.  It's good.  Really good.  Unique sushi.  Make sure to have some.  Fish selection here is incredible.  Many varieties I have never tried before.  So fresh and so clean!  The Yellowtail cooked in the hot stone bowl was delicious.  The smell just lingered at the table.  The fish was succulent.  I also enjoyed the Seafood Toban Yaki -- sort of like a seafood stew/hotpot on crack -- lobster, king crab, huge prawns, scallops, in a rich miso sake broth.  Do not pass on the desserts here.  Normally, I don't get desserts at Asian restaurants.  Finally, a place that can elevate desserts!  Had a sorbert trio -- I think one of the selections was a raspberry wasabi sorbert.  It was very unique.  I won't forget it ever.  Also, the cheesecake was amazing.  Nothing like I have ever tried before.  The cake was light and airy yet full of flavor.  Loved every part of the meal.  Also, it's like dining in a modern museum -- sensory overload.

YUM YUM YUM. I love everything about this place. I have been here dozens of times and have never been disappointed. Order the fresh tofu made at your table. YUMGreat atmosphere and I've always had friendly servers.GO HERE

Iron Chef Morimoto on style on TV tempted us to come here for a meal here. The menu seems endless and we wanted to try everything.  We decided on the Morimoto omakase, 8 course tasting menu designed to allow you to experience the essence of Morimoto's cuisine.  I started with the White Lily cocktail and love it.  The food took its time, and that was good since I was totally enjoying my $14 drink.First was tuna tartar, beautifully presented and very different from what we had from other places, this came in a rectangle wood tray (like color paint).  It was quite interesting to find out that this item was 1st featured on Iron Chef Show and now on his menu.Second was fluke sashimi with roasted hot oil. Hot oil totally gives the plate its highlight.Third is the sear salmon with micro green. Salmon was cook half raw, and it made it enjoyable.Ordered the 2nd White Lily cocktail, but this time; it tasted too sweet for the courses. We added sake.Fourth was AMAZING! The combinations of foie gras, raw oyster and of course (my fav) uni just melt in my mouth. I can have this everyday.. Perfect dish!! Did I say another round of that plz?Fifth was variety kind of sushi, the fish slices were bit thin so that could be improve, as we'll here because for the love of 'raw fish'. So I like some more than other but everything was very fresh.  We sat close to the sushi bar area, so I got to see the Sushi Chef created our dish, he was quite concentrated; and the 'folding' of sushi to create the shape was continuously the same amount of turns. Very interesting and good learning for me.Sixth & Seventh came in one, kobe beef and shiny lobster. For $60 extra, they would replace kobe from Japan instead of American Kobe beef. We had pix taken of the Japanese kobe beef when our waiter brought it out to show us about the marbles and it was hugh piece.  I wanted one to take home. lolEighth was the desert, peach sorbet pair with sweet bread.Overall, the service was excellent, and he got tip well, we also received a signed Moromoto menu. It was a night of GOOD EATS.

Awesome, amazing 5-star experience!  Highlights were the whitefish carpaccio and the wagyu fillet with sweet onion jus.  That was one of the best steaks I've ever had in my life.  Every dish was beautifully plated and very flavorful. The atmosphere is hip and trendy, but warm at the same time.  There was a very fun vibe in the restaurant the entire night.  Our server, Pat, rocked.  He was super friendly and very helpful with the menu.  Morimoto is great on so many levels.  I highly recommend it.

I don't watch television, so when my friend was so excited about having her birthday dinner at Morimoto that she was bouncing up and down, it was lost on me.  Before we even headed there, she was reading the menu online deciding what to order because she didn't want to "miss anything amazing."So.  Naturally.  I was skeptical.We arrived right on time for our 9:45 PM reservation (it was all that was available) and were greeted by a lovely young woman who informed us that our table "was a little behind" and directed us to the lounge downstairs for a cocktail.  The bartenders were very nice and the drink menu was trendy.  So.  Naturally.  I asked for a single malt, up.Blink, blink went the bartender.  But to his credit he recovered quickly and suggested that I try a Japanese single malt.  (Who knew?)  So I did, and it was actually not bad.  The cocktails that my friends ordered were infused-vodka based and predictably sweet.30 minutes passed and we still hadn't been seated.  It is now 10:15 PM.  As my friend got up to go check on our reservation, the bartender stopped her and called up to the hostess stand, which miraculously led to us being seated immediately.The lack of ability to seat us at our reservation time - or even within a reasonable time period around it (in a restaurant that was not packed to the gills - pardon the pun) is my only complaint about Morimoto.From the moment we sat down, the experience was delightful.  The design of the space creates intimacy while maintaining an open feeling.  Our server was knowledgeable, appropriately attentive and made reasonable suggestions.  The wine list was good and the sake flight was a fun departure from the usual.As far as the food goes, it was all fantastic.  Flavors mingled nicely with one another, portions were appropriately-sized to allow for sampling a wide variety of the menu, and everything was served at the perfect temperature, which may seem like an odd thing to note, but when you are having everything from burrata to oysters on the half shell to Peking duck, it matters.And while I still have no idea what the TV show is all about that brought Morimoto to the forefront (of course it could be that the chef came from Nobu) I am definitely a fan and can say that this is one of the select dining experiences that fires on all fronts and touches all of your senses.You should go.

Loved our dinner here! Started off a little rocky because we were originally by the bar and all of a sudden, the glass fell over and hit my knee. Called the waiter over and took care of us. The manager sat us down somewhere else and offered us an extra dish with our omakase. It was D-LI-CIOUS!!! No one really asked how my knee was but I guess that's beside the point. Omakase was a 7 dish meal. Everything was amazing. Party in my mouth!! Fish tasted fresh. Morimoto is truly a genius when it comes to flavors, presentation, and creativity. Call me a freak but I judge a restaurant by their restrooms as well and his restroom by far is the BEST looking restroom I've ever seen. He installed an updated bidet with a pleasant 3-D effect wall as you're facing the toilet. Morimoto is a place you'd want to experience!

Wow. Morimoto was an amazing culinary experience. In my opinion, it beats Buddakan and Nobu. My boyfriend and I shared the following: -Rock Shrimp Tempura -Toro Tartare-Spicy Yellowtail maki roll-Braised Black Cod -Sea Bass-Monkey Bread-White Lily Cocktail The rock shrimp was delicious. It was served with two different sauces plus a homemade ranch sauce and cucumbers for dipping. It was a generous appetizer portion. The toro tartare had a beautiful presentation and I loved the idea that it was an interactive appetizer and you could create your own flavors depending on what sauce you dipped your tuna in. I thought the tuna was an extremely thin layer and was hoping for more tuna since it was a $30 appetizer. The sushi felt fresh and was good but wasn't different than any other good sushi spot. Both the sea bass and black cod melted in your mouth. They were both equally delicious but felt the sea bass was a bigger portion simply since the sea bass is a meatier fish. The sea bass came with an avocado tempura that was tasty.The black cod came with a few black beans that were sweet and delicious. If you like sweeter sauces, definitely go for the cod. The monkey bread was served with a banana brioche, homemade caramel sauce, and a banana chocolate chip ice cream. I don't even like monkey bread but it was tasty.The white lily cocktail is their signature cocktail and it tasted like lemonade- so light! I loved it. Everything at Morimoto was beautifully presented and the service was impeccable. I highly recommend trying it out but be warned that it is pricey.PS- The bathroom is one of the coolest bathrooms I've ever seen in NYC. So great.

Excellent service and food, although for a price.All of my friends decided to get the 7 course omakase except me. It's nice because not the entire table has to order the tasting menu, and my friends were nice enough to let me taste a bit of each one.In general, I thought the tasting menu was a neat experience to try once, but at $125, I wouldn't go back and order it again. One of the courses was just slices of several different vegetables that you dipped into a warm sauce, and another was a single oyster. Rather than getting all 7 courses, if I were to go back, I'd just get the 2-3 the courses I liked. Which were:Surf and turf (amazing lobster)Sushi (really fresh)The toro tartare seemed overhyped to me - barely any toro for an extremely high price.I ordered my own choices from the menu which were:ishi yaki buri bop - This was a really fun dish. They cooked the fish on the hot stone bowl right in front of me, and the person cooked the fish just perfectly so that it was tender and melted in my mouth - somewhere between sashimi and fully cooked fish. I love bibimbap, so obviously loved the buri bop, although my one gripe was that I didn't really like the spices (can't handle spicy foods at all).Tofu Cheescake - My FAVORITE thing from the meal. Get this to share because it's a sizeable dessert with two parts. The tofu cheescake was delicious and light and not overpoweringly sweet the way many desserts often are. Plus I LOVED the azuki cream, which was again airy and sweet, and it paired perfectly with the slightly bitter green tea ice cream. You must try this! It will revolutionize the way you see tofu.All in all, a pricy meal if you go omakase, but can definitely be made more reasonable if you just order specific items off the menu (which I recommend as the way to go). Don't miss out on the desserts!

I've been wanting to go to Morimoto ever since..f-o-r-e-v-e-r! I remember talking about visiting the restaurant a few years back with a couple of friends, but our plans never worked out. SO! when the 2011 Restaurant Week list came out, I knew this was going to be my chance to get affordable (and good) Japanese food......ok, and mayyybe get a chance to meet the Iron Chef himself. The interior of the restaurant is really chic and modern - suitable for young professionals, students, as well as the elderly crowd. Since it was restaurant week, the place was (no doubt) bustling with people. Prior to our food, I ordered a non-alcoholic coconut drink topped with basil. Highly recommended for anyone who loves coconut!Even though we wanted to take advantage of the restaurant week prices, we couldn't help but look through the menu at other available options. As an extra side, we ordered the Tuna Tartare which was cleverly presented and super delicious! The sauces were laid out nicely on a rectangle wooden tray which included: fresh wasabi, sour cream, seaweed puree, chopped up green onions, avocado, and little rice cracker balls. We certainly attracted a lot of wandering eyes when this dish came out. The tuna itself was very fresh and light. I really liked the combo of rice cracker balls and seaweed puree with the tuna. The lunch prix fixe they offered came in an oversized bento box. We ordered the waygu and black cod bento box set. The set came with miso soup, fresh salad, fried tempura w/ some sort of creamy sauce, and sushi/sashimi. Unfortunately, the portions were a little tiny (I'll admit that I can eat more than the average girl, but believe me when I say the portions were definitely on the smaller side). I felt bad for the big hungry man across from us. Poor dude. The waygu beef was a little too salty, ordinary, and again...too small of a portion. The black cod on the other hand was great - with just the right touch of sweetness.The dessert served was a Green Tea Coconut Panna Cotta with berries on top. Taste was good, but nothing spectacular. The service was great considering our waitress had many tables to juggle due to restaurant week. Judging by the Tuna Tartare off the restaurant's original menu (not restaurant week menu), I would come back here again to try their other mouthwatering dishes!Overall: 3.8/5

I'm taking off one star because they make you wait until your whole party arrives in front of the freezing cold entrance, even if you have a reservation and the restaurant isn't even half full.  You can't let us sit?  Or wait in the bar area?  Lame.Aside from that, the service is great and the food is awesome. Came here for restaurant week lunch, and the bento boxes were wonderful. Dessert was amazing.  Once I get a raise, we'll come back for real. :)

Came for lunch. When we first approached the restaurant, we thought it was closed, as it had giant cloth banners hanging in front of the door. However, once we stepped beyond the cloth, the doors slid open and proved us wrong. The decor is streamlined and simplistic. The place was rather empty - not many people here during lunchtime on a Saturday.The waitress was courteous and attentive and promptly brought my requested pot of tea with honey. For sushi, she recommended the chu-toro over the oh-toro, and we also got the scallop. In addition, I ordered a spicy tuna handroll. The sushi was really good.We then had the wagyu beef carpaccio, which was decent although non-conventional. For starters, the beef was half cooked on one side, and the slices were not so traditionally thin. However, the sauce was pretty good.For main, my friend ordered the sea bass, and we both agreed it was one of the best sea bass we have had in the city. I had the seafood toban yaki, a huge stew dish that comes with rice. The broth was good, but the seafood inside was a bit overcooked. The scallops were a bit rubbery, and the shrimp was rather tasteless.Would like to return and try more of the menu.

The appetizers are the real stand-out- especially the foie gras oysters. All of them were great- fresh made tofu, wagyu carpaccio, toro tartar. Oh and the bread pudding dessert, wow. The sushi was great, but didn't blow me away. Unbelievable service. 2 weird things: The meal for 4 lasted 3.5 hours!! just for 5 appetizers and the sushi combo and dessert. And then I was thirsty for like 2 days. I woke up all night because I was just so thirsty.

I adore Morimoto. I grew up watching him on Iron Chef and always admired his creativity. I've been wanting to go for at least RW but I could never make it since they only offered it for lunch. So, my bf and I went to Morimoto to celebrate our three year anniversary. The dinner was everything I've expected (except for the rain.........and Morimoto not being present during our visit). I did wish however that we were seated on the main floor but we had an intimate dinner with the view of the restaurant.  The first floor had a clean and sparkly atmosphere while the basement had more of a up beat/nightlight feeling. The bathroom was absolutely beautiful - very Zen like, I could stay there forever.Started off with a lychee martini - I forgot the name. I was a little upset that it was nothing special but a friend already had warned me so shame on me. We thought about ordering the omakase for $120 but we REALLY wanted to try the Morimoto sashimi...So here's a list of what we ordered:Morimoto sashimi - Bite size sashimi pieces.. Don't get me wrong, it was good but I can't remember the sauces. I liked the presentation over the actual dish.Toro tartar - I wish I had this for myself. I never thought toro went well with crème fraiche! My favorite was the nori paste with the fresh wasabi.Chef's combination $75 - awesome minus the shrimp tempura roll that I didn't care for...sad faceSea bass - WOW, the fish was so flaky and the tempura avocado was to die for. My favorite dish of the night! I devoured it like a mad womanFlourless chocolate cake with caramel popcorn - hm, not sure if this was executed correctly. There's a lot of stuff going on.I definitely would like to try his hot appetizers and main courses especially the Duck, Duck, Duck. The sushi was good but I feel like it's not worth it unless Morimoto makes it himself. If you haven't been here yet.. What are you waiting for?
Sashimi and sushi heaven! You have to experience this orgasmic culinary beauty!Lunch is affordable, can be quite pricey for dinner but worth every dollar!

This is a pretty restaurant, but it seems sort of dated - all cream colored and lucite.     Very big, although I really couldn't tell you much because we were seated at a table where my chair was flush to a wall and I was looking at a wall, even though there were many empty tables.  Could have said something, but didn't, so that's on me.  My wife got reservations on Open Table that  same day, and we were very excited.   Things started well after that.   Waitress was initially very attentive, brought me a sample of shochu - a Japanese drink - which I liked and ordered.   For appetizers we had the seasonal Japanese apps, and those were very tasty.   We ordered some special she recommended - lobster and kimchi roll to share - nothing special and it had a spring roll tucked inside which tasted like standard Chinese restaurant egg roll to a T.  After that things sort of continued downhill.   For mains I had the chirashi sushi and my wife had the salmon.  Both were ok, but nothing my Brooklyn neighborhood sushi place would not have provided equally.   Service was not good; after her initial burst of care, our waitress kept away too long, our plates took way too long to be cleaned, water refills were slow.   We only got to ask for a second round of drinks because we grabbed a busboy's attention.  And then by the time the waitress came back with a drink menu and then returned to take our drink orders I was two thirds through the main and didn't want a drink.   It was the sort of situation where we were trying hard to catch her eye just to get the check so we could leave.   The table to our left was twice brought food which should have gone to the table one further down.  "And here's your tuna pizza, no anchovies - this isn't yours".  "And here's your vegetarian sushi. Oops, I'm sorry?"  The other customer and I exchanged glances and laughed after the second time, but this really shouldn't happen at these prices; we all like the illusion that our food is pristine and untouched, particularly sushi, so seeing it bounce off the next table over is somewhat unsettling.   Bathrooms were cool - I did like the Japanese toilets, and the decor was very serene.   Our discussion when we were leaving was "I hate to say meh, but meh.   If we had eaten near home the table would have been better placed, the service would have been way better and the food would have been the same.   And we would have saved probably $90."   Sad to say, not really worth the hype.
Great ambiance, went for a birthday treat, pre fixed 5 course meal with table side service.

There's absolutely nothing left to say about this place that hasn't been said in the other 1,141 reviews... but for my 2 cents: the best meal I've ever had in NYC. Not to mention I've been enamored by Masaharu Morimoto ever since watching him on the Japanese Iron Chef as a tween... I would always be completely offended if someone suggested he didn't win the battle :)

I've always wanted to try this place after seeing chef morimoto on iron chef. I'm so glad I did. I love the ambiance and setting of the restaurant. It's very modern and elegant. We were greeted and seated very promptly. Our waitress was very friendly and have wonderful recommendations on the starters. We started with the miso glazed roasted bone marrow and sautéed foie gras & grilled eel. The bone marrow was so flavorful. The foie gras was cooked perfectly and has just the right amount of flavor. They did a very good job presenting the dish with decorative pear pieces and lemon sauce drops. I ordered the chef combination sashimi and sushi. Both were incredibly fresh and tasty. Last but not least, my favorite part of the meal was the amazing green tea layer crepe cake. I was surprised on how strong the green tea taste was and not overly sweet. Overall, it met my expectation and I would definitely  go back to try other dishes. Oh and make sure you visit the restroom.

We came here on NYE 2013 for dinner.  Our table wasn't ready yet so we were ushered downstairs to have a cocktail and were escorted up maybe 25 minutes after our reservation time to be seated.  The decor is very chic and modern..I loved the displays in the bathroom and the igloo setup at the bar.  It was easy to have our bar tab put on our dinner bill, which was great.What we got:4 Stars - 2 cocktails -  ume martini and cinnamon apple whiskey, both were pretty good2 Stars - Junmai Sake - we weren't trying to spend big bucks on dinner drinks since we were planning to drink the rest of the night up until NYE, so we chose the low grade sake.  Big mistake. For $22 you'd expect at least a decent tasting sake, but this one was harsh and difficult to drink.4 Stars - Toro Tartare - I love interactive food.  It doesn't disappoint in terms of flavor palettes, the choice between the many sauces including wasabi, seaweed paste, rice cracker, dashi-soy, sour cream, etc..  lends way to a really fun and interesting starter.  It's much smaller in person than it looks in the pictures, but I'm not surprised since it IS toro and there's also caviar on it.  I could've eaten that all day.4 Stars - Foie Gras Oysters - Oh my my my.  This was my favorite dish by far.  The explosion of flavor isn't comparable.  My 3 favorite things in one bite, what more could I ask for?  The only negative was that there was too my teri sauce.. I would've preferred something less sweet.  Flipside, I loved the berry palette cleanser, which was sweet and refreshing.3 Stars - Chef's Selection Sushi - Nothing too special, just assorted nigiri of chef's selection fish.3 Stars - Chef's Selection Sashimi - Again, nothing too noteworthy except for the maguro, which in my opinion was the best I've ever had.  Normally maguro (tuna) is pretty tasteless but in this case, it was surprisingly very flavorful.4 Stars - Flourless Chocolate Cake - Very unique dessert.  It was a lava type choco cake accompanied by a pear sorbet and caramel popcorn, grapes, pomegranate, flowers, and other fruits.  It looked like an array of opposing flavors but once I tried it, it went very well together.5 Stars Service - Service was impeccable.  I would have preferred a more private table since we were seated within touching distance of the parties next to us, but otherwise, our server and the bussers were great.Probably won't be back since there were so many other great places to try in NYC, but I would say my overall experience was a good one.

WHAT THE ....I expected too much I think.Appetizers were the only thing that saved this experience from crashing and burning.From entering the door, this place has a sterile warehouse kind of ambiance. Floors are made of plain concrete, wall art is recycled bottles. Totally plain. The bathroom door is a death trap, and whats inside is worse. Did not expect that at all. The bartender with stupid hair is a smart ass.Waiter was a bit nervous, but was sincere, so he got a good tip. My god-parents were only semi-impressed, again, only with the appetizers. The rest of the experience was very empty, and lacking.Work on the decor, the music, the damned floors... for the love of... make this place look like you want a Mich star.Iron shamble.
It's always been the PERFECT place for special occasions. Their sushi is pretty good but not the best but the drinks, dessert, and special appetizers are to die for.

I wish there was an option for two-and-a-half stars...Obviously, I was left underwhelmed. Considering Masaharu Morimoto's reputation not only as an Iron Chef, but also one of the most acclaimed Japanese chefs in the country, I expected to be blown away. But alas. The food was average -- some dishes decidedly better than the others, and some just forgettable. In that sense, I found the standards inconsistent. Service was decent. Not terribly impressed with the decor. The bar (located downstairs) feels really cold and gloomy. Bathrooms, however, are beautiful and ridiculously hi-tech just as you'd expect from any self-respecting Japanese restaurant.
Super pricey but worth it! Excellent during lunch hours when it's not busy. Great Asian fusion if you enjoy that type of cuisine and have a big of extra money to burn.

Always happy with this spot. Good food, good ambience. Sometimes these celeb chef places can be cheesy but this is a really well put together spot.I have been here about 3 times in 2012 Q4.Lobster rolls area must, so is the martini with elder flower.On my last visit we had the tofu which was made and steamed right in front of us, it was made, poured, and let to sit at our table, whereas 30 minutes later (while we were eating other items) the server came to open it , slice it and serve it to us, and also serve the appropriate dressings on it.The service is hit and miss, sometimes when busy, the servers are not attentive and forgetful but when the service is good - it is really good.Overall - decor is beautiful, good to people watch. Not pretentious. Good food. I would always come back here 80% of the coming back would be for the food.Walking distance from some hot spots to party in meatpacking district...also a plus.NOTE:  Yes, the bathrooms are MAGNIFICENTLY COOL.

Located on the far west side of manhattan across the st from colicchio and sons and del posto, this Japanese place is usually our go to late eats place because we almost always get in without reservations.  Our default dish is the chirashi which costs $30 and comes with huge fresh chunks of assorted fish on a bed of delicious white rice.  Ive also had their wagyu rib eye which is also pretty delicious.   They also have pretty good cocktails, and sake.  The sake is pricey though, some of the most expensive Ive seen in the city.  Price isnt cheap, but quality is there and usually never a wait.  Oh and check out the restrooms!

I've been here a couple of times. The first time was such a good experience that I had to come back and take my boyfriend here the following month. I do have to mention that I live in California. The place: ambience is very nice and fancy. the place has 2 floors. most of the seating is upstairs. downstairs is where the bar is. If you are here, you have to drop by the bathroom downstairs. Very pretty bathroom with a bidet!The drinks: lots of yummy cocktails. I personally liked the hydangea and and white lily.the food: Australian wagyu rib eye was one of the best steaks i've had. very tender and wonderful flavor. definitely not cheap, but if you aren't hungry---definitely can share this one. this was the dish that urge me to come back the second time!I also had the sea bass here and it was also very delicious. the duck was also very good. if you get a chance--get the braised pork belly as an appetizer--it's very delicious!definitely recommend this place for any special occasion or just because!!

Went with the wife and had:(app) Miso glazed roasted bone marrow (-1) - Delicious, fatty, bone marrow was so savory. However, the chimichurri sauce was too spicy for my wife and the grilled sourdough was left on a grill far too long. It felt like eating charcoal.(entree) Duck duck duck (-0.5)- Wife loved it so much she almost didn't want to share it; duck was perfect and perfectly cooked egg was delicious.. I had a bite of the croissant stuffed with duck and the croissant was soggy. It was either sitting out so long the duck steamed the croissant, or the duck was not allowed to rest long enough before plating..(entree) Ishi yaki buri bop - This was so good, yellowtail is cooked on outside and raw on inside, with savory vegetables on a bed of rice. Definitely one of the larger entrees on the menu.Service: (-0.5)- It took like 30 mins to get our appetizer and 30 mins to get our entrees.Overall, it was tasty, but probably not worth the hype compared to other places in NYC.

AMAZING!I came here with my entire family for our annual Christmas dinner. We all had the tasting menu and were salivating from the moment we first saw our dishes to the very last bite. This place does not mess around with food, and I'm pretty sure anything on the menu is spectacular. The space itself has a great vibe as well, and would be nice to meet up and share a drink in the bar/lounge downstairs. What I loved was how nice it was, but not too stuffy that you felt like you needed to whisper or couldn't speak normally. It felt comfortable to be in there. I can't say enough good things about this place!! You will not be disappointed!
Outstanding. Great food , unique hip atmosphere. One of. A kind : special occasion experience. Very expensive but worth it .

I waited for my second visit to this place because on the first we got omakase on my dads dime so of course that was amazing. After spending my own $100+ on an a la carte selection I can now verify this place is worth the price and a must try for fans of new school Japanese food. My recommendations include scallop congee with pork belly, oyster with foie gras and the surf and turf. Extra points from me because they serve their own brand of morimoto beer made by rouge ales of Oregon. The soba beer was an interesting twist on Amber wheat ale and I might go back just to try the morimoto hazelnut ale. Love the look and feel of the room with open kitchen and comfy seating; service was excellent the first time and decent the second. The only Japanese meal I've had that is as good was at nobu which I recently discovered is where the iron chef worked before opening his own place.
Tuna tartare is really good.  I love the omakase.  It's pricy, but def worth it.  Is on par with the Philly location.

Food was overall decent, but I wouldn't go back voluntarily. Every dish was more of a presentational gimmick than focused on the actual flavors. My dining partner from Tokyo was disappointed at how the quality of food has diminished significantly since last year. Service was brisk at best, rude at times.- Toro Tartare: Icy. + Fois Gras Chawan Mushi: Two things I love in one cup. Creamy, rich, yellow.- Pork Gyoza: Surprisingly large. Obviously added for diners who want to play it safe.+ Yosedofu: Fresh tofu is always amazing.- Ramen Soup: Broth was standard, noodles felt pre-packaged.+ Braised Black Cod: Great sweet fish, not overcooked at all.+ Baba au Rhume: Mont Blanc's hot older brother. A must for chestnut lovers.+ Tofu Hot and Cold: Not too rich or heavy with just enough sweetness.AMBIENCE- Table: I wish they would tell me when I'm going to sit next to a complete stranger at a communal table. Not only do I not play well with others, this isn't breakfast at  Le Pain Quotidienne where I'm perfectly happy to nibble my croissant and watch "Mad Men" in blissful ignorance of some producer sitting next to me on his Bluetooth headset for the entirety of my meal/episode.+ Bathroom: Best part of the entire restaurant, no exaggeration. The mirrored cherry blossom background made me forget why I was there in the first place. After that visual delight my senses were more than ready to go to third base with the bidet.

Horrendous service, unprecedentedly bad in my experiences dining at similarly upscale restaurants. Our main waiter made an extremely rude comment when we tried to ask him something as he was walking past us. Those who described the dishes didn't bother to articulate and just muttered something indistinguishable under their breath and scurried off.The food was not worth the price tag. Our underwhelming toro tartare was $30. The presentation is indeed unique but after that, there's pretty much nothing else to the dish. We also got the spicy king crab ... Worst decision ever. For $36, we got crab with spicy mayo... Fresh? Maybe a step above cafeteria boxed sushi. Thus, we spent over $60 on disappointing appetizers with the smallest portions (this is coming from someone who rarely clears her plates and is in no means saying quantity trumps quality... The quality here is just subpar.) Finally, the saving grace was the black cod which was soft and dressed in a delicious teriyaki sauce which was slightly too salty but the highlight of our lunch. Lastly, we had an incoherent apple bread dessert with ice cream on the side and a fun mousse and green tea crumbs. Decor was trendy and chic as expected but the bathrooms are nothing to wow about.Considering this was a highly anticipated restaurant for us, we could not leave more disappointed. However, Morimoto's fame will guarantee this restaurant many diners, but there are countless Japanese restaurants in New York City that serve the same, if not better quality food and definitely provide better service and lower prices.

Trendy as hell. Expensive as hell. Beautiful interior design. Good looking people all around. The food is still the best part. Indulge in Morimoto, then get chicken & rice for the next couple days. One of the best sashimi I've tasted. Highlight: Omakase (menu tasting for $120+ per person)Course No.1: Toro tartare. Not your typical fat slab of tuna or what you'd imagine "fatty" tuna to look like. But this thin sheet of toro is impressive. The creativity and unique combination of sauces are intriguing.Course No. 2: Sashimi. Raw fish is the bread and butter of this Japanese restaurant as it should be. But they probably have good bread and butter too.Course #3: Salad with Hot Anchovies Sauce. Nice idea. Fishy. Course #4: Uni + Kumamoto Oyster. Perfect.  Course #5: Sashimi. Back to the basics.Course #6: Wangyu beef + crab + lobster. I wish I had a bowl of rice to chomp this course down with. The spices and powerful taste on this course made the Omakase very memorable. Course #7: Dessert. Is this place a dessert specialist house? Good finish!* I wouldn't order the ramen. Sure its hand-made noodles. But its the size of a cup of noodle and there is so much good ramen in NY and LA that you don't need to come here to mess around with stuff like that.

Excellent Japanese.  The Wagyu (sp?) was excellent, but not quite Sparks/Del Friscos.  (However, it was better than Lugars)Solid service, each course was very good.  Not cheap but not overly expensive.  Would definitely go again.

Great food, enjoyed all three dishes I had (the seared scallops are great for starters!) Decor and service were nice. Presentation is faultless. The waiter mixed up my receipts though and charged me extra at first.
It was a long time ago that I went to the West Side location.   Food was great and  Morimoto was actually in the restaurant and took a photo with us.  those were the days.

It was very disappointed for lunch.  My husband and I ate Yellow Tail Tartar and Dobinmushi as appetizer.  They were delicious but there was no Matsutake in Dobinmushi which was very disappointed and did not enjoy Kaori for that.  Tartar was very delicious.We ate Morimoto Chirashi on the tray as a main dish.  I felt very salty for Miso-soup, cucumber and Hijiki.  Some tofu in Miso soup was good. Then, Chirashi was in very round bawl which was not very convenience for taking fish and other because they cut very small and less rice which I've expected.  Then, the waitress put dinner price of Chirashi but my husband noticed and asked if it was right or not.  She apologized.Totally, it was very expensive for lunch but not fully satisfied except restaurant ambience.

Freshest sushi in ny....delectable entrées everything I would expect from an iron chef's restaurant. Imppecable service as well. Definitely will return to try his wagyu at 40$/lb my wallet simply wasn't ready yet lol.

Go here for a true experience restaurant.  Amazing atmosphere.  From the unassuming but once you see it awe inspiring entrance to the bathrooms with toilets that have more remote control buttons than my dvd player remote.  Also, the food is really good.TIP! Hard place to find with no address; look for sliding doors with red cloth over them and japanese lettering.  No sign I could see from the street.  Make sure you have an address and you will be fine.We were tourists walking around the city for the day so we were a bit underdressed in jeans.  No one made us feel bad and the service was excellent across the board.  Everyone working in the restaurant was friendly and professional. Server made some excellent recommendations.  She recommended the toro tartare (28$) which I am sad we did not get (according to reviews here on yelp) and she recommended the cod (23$).  We ordered the morimoto sashimi (28$) which was good but a little steep price wise.  It was 6 little square stacks of 5 thinly sliced sashimi pieces (5 different fish).  It was tasty with the different sauces.  The cod absolutely won me over.  Delicious sauce, great toppings (shaved ginger) and had some type of pickled vegetable and black beans on the side which went great with the fish.  Fish melted in your mouth.  I didn't ever think COD could do that!  We also had a 40$ sushi combination, the sushi was just good, the spicy tuna roll that came with it was really good though.We were a little hungry after splitting those dishes and wound up getting 2 desserts.  Apple turban (12$) was very good with fresh apple slices, chopped pineapple underneath, and delicious cinnamon ice cream.  We also had the flourless chocolate cake (12$) which was hit and miss.  The cake had apple slices in it and rhubarb ice cream.  I did not like the rhubarb ice cream at all.  Apple slices were stuck inside the the top of the cake pieces but was not a good mix together.  Cake itself was amazing but very only 4 small pieces of it.  If they could do a huge piece of this cake without all the other extra crap I would get it again and again and again.As for atmosphere it gets no better.  This place was extremely well designed.  You will be ooo and awwwing the entire time.  Make sure you check out the bathrooms, they are works of the art as is the glass wall in the middle of the restaurant.  This was better than the Guggenheim.  You will not be disappointed here.To make it a great date check out the elevated highline park (entrance is only a couple blocks away).  Park has great views of the city and was built on an abandoned subway track (above street level).  Truly a unique night for us.

Celebrated my twin girl friends birthday there. The food is of course VERY VERY good. It was my second time there and I am definitely going back for omakase next time. We ordered a la carte and it came out a little over on the expensive side, but it was worth it. We brought our own candles and asked them to stick it on the desserts that we ordered. The chef/waiter decorated the plate beautifully! We were all snapping photos for like 5 minutes until the wax of the candles were half on the plate lol lovely place as usual. I think this would be a perfect place for a date or a special celebration. Oh, the bathroom downstairs is an attraction itself!
very nice place! love the food! Service can improve, the toilet seat was surprising , it's automatic!!! ...will definitely go back...
Really good sushi- service is generally good- drinks are good- but you will pay (we are used to that in NY aren't we). Can be a bit busy and loud- depends on the night.

Amazing and delicious. Yes it is expensive as you can see from the copious number of receipt pictures. However, it is an experience with great ambiance, delicious drinks, incredible presentation and food that makes you want to close your eyes and savor each and every bite. Yum.

Visited Morimoto a few weeks ago for on a day trip to NYC for lunch. I may never be able to eat sushi anywhere else ever again, now that I've tasted perfection.The mixed drinks are surprisingly awesome. Worth the price? I'm not sure, but definitely worth taking a look.Because it was lunch, we decided to just fill up on sushi, so I can't speak on the other food. The sushi was amazing though! We tried a few different things, and everything was yummy and fresh. No regrets on anything!Ladies, the bathroom -- you have to check it out. Before you have a drink though, because it's a little scary after one too many. Try all of the buttons. I will leave you to do your own exploration.Because I don't live in NY, I probably won't be doing Morimoto again. However, if he ever decided to open a place in Boston, I will welcome him with open arms and an empty stomach!
Beautiful inside, great food. Service mediocre. Pricey for food you pay for ambiance!
Had the 5 course meal. Best meal of my life! If you have the opportunity to go to Morimoto run don't walk.
Ambience was nice, food was great & fresh, service was also on point. Great place to go w/ a date. My husband & I enjoyed it!

The food was so well-balanced. for every part of my bento box i told my fellow diner "this is what tempura SHOULD be like"/ "this is what sushi SHOULD be like"/etc. we tried the cod and the bass bento box. a pretty good-sized meal. the BEST tempura i've had in my life. the breading was light and crispy and seasoned and the gorgonzola sauce was an unexpected amazing pairing. our server was SO polite and sweet. it was really a pleasure to dine with him. the only hiccup was the black sesame panna cotta. a very peculiar taste. i didn't dislike but actually ended up eating the WHOLE thing trying to figure out how i felt about it. very excited to come back and see what else the menu has to offer.
Overrated in my opinion, nothing was remarkable and we had soysauce that tasted of soap. Server tried to play it off like it was supposed to be that way. This place was unfortunately a let down.

I'm speechless when it comes to Morimoto NYC. Just. Go. Can't go wrong with anything here.Just don't get the "ramen."  But everything Last Words: Stellar Sushi. Exceptional Entrees. Astounding Ambiance.
Service, Ambiance, Food and Drinks were FANTASTIC!!! I will definitely go back to try the other dishes.

My husband surprised me with dinner here for my birthday.  We had the Omakase (tasting menu).  It's 7 courses that take you through all the different parts of the menu.  Its $125 per person (without drinks), but it was our first time eating here, so its was the perfect way to try a little of everything. I loved the service; everyone was really attentive.  As dishes were set on the table they'd explain what it is and how you eat it (picture the way Morimoto explains to the panel of judges on Iron Chef).  Everything was really good!  Oh and try the cocktail with the sesame infused vodka. Yum!

Morimoto is Iron Chef for a reason. He really knows his flavors and experiments and presents new and unique dishes. Presentation of the food is art. The quality of the dishes were superb but the portions were definitely small. But nonetheless, great.The interior design of this place is flawless, down to the dishware and utensils. Loved the glass wall and the textures on the ceiling and walls. Chic. Classy. PS. We saw Guy Fieri at the bar downstairs. Yeah, we made eye contact. Also, this place has the swankiest bathrooms/toilets. Take a gander to the restroom, you'll never come out.

Amazing! What a great experience. When we were first seated the area was a room off to the side and very stuffy. But the staff was great and moved us to the sushi bar. So glad we did - great interaction. We did the tasting menu and it was wonderful. Can't wait to go back!

Look, I'm not nearly hip enough for the Meatpacking district but I decided to take my non-ironic beard and my hot wife for a date on our fifteenth anniversary because she's a sushi fan and I'm an Iron Chef fan.  I could see this going either way - either the Iron Chef could phone it in and count on his fame to bring in the customers, or he could cook some excellent food.  He did the latter.Morimoto was absolutely wonderful.  The meal was perhaps the best meal I've ever had in NYC.  The staff was fantastic and the restaurant itself was gorgeous.  Both my wife and I were thoroughly impressed.  I'd go back in a heartbeat.
This place makes very good fancy Japanese food with a focus on sushi, but it is extremely expensive relative to the high but not outstanding quality.

I think the franchise had grown too fast.  I've met Morimoto before and he does not seem like the type of person who would let his product slide.  The complain I had was that the rice was dry.  That is a big no-no!  I'm gonna wait until next time to review this place again because I'm a big fan of the Philly Morimoto

I'm honestly a bit surprised with Morimoto in the sense that I wasn't really wowed by anything I had ordered. I never mind shelling out a whole lot of money for a really good or fancy meal but for the amount I spent at Morimoto's wasn't really worth it.I took two friends here for a late night dinner and for appetizers we ordered the  Toro Tartare, Steamed Scallops, Foie Gras Chawan Mushi. The Toro Tartare was okay, I honestly wasn't sure exactly what was so special about it. Steamed Scallops were good and was cooked just right. The Foie Gras Chawan Mushi was.... interesting, I honestly wasn't sure what I thought about this dish. It was interesting, and tasted decent but there was something about the texture/feel in my mouth that I wasn't a fan of. As for our entrees we ordered the Spicy Salmon Roll, Salmon Skin Role, the Wagyu Beef Roll, and the Chirashi Bowl. All the rolls were okay, nothing special or out of the ordinary but for the most part the fish tasted pretty fresh. The Wagyu Beef Roll was a little bit plain in my opinion but was really tender and pretty good. The Chirashi Bowl came out and although it was beautiful and had a whole lot of chunks of fish, the fish didn't really taste all that fresh. I honestly couldn't finish the bowl (and this bowl was split between 3 people and we were still unable to finish it). Overall, if you were to ask me I'd say the food isn't bad, but it's not spectacular either and given the price I probably won't be returning again.

The food is awesome but the ambiance ok! We dined there last night and while I was def. blown away by the food and the unique  bathroom door, the ambiance and the place itself was a little let down. In terns of decor nothing much to rave about. So if you are looking for a fancy place look elsewhere. To get over the bathroom mystery, the door slides and to lock it from inside, there is a switch on the wall. You flip the switch which locks and unlocks the door. The bathroom is all white, very zen like and that's abt it! There the mystery is over!Now for the food: The Toro Tartare was excellent. Not only did it taste fresh and delicious, the presentation was superb. The Japanese Lobster fritters were delicious but unlike fritters these were not crispy or crunchy. In fact they were almost like soft, doughy balls filled with lobster. Delicious nonetheless. The 2 sushi rolls  - Shrimp tempura roll and the soft shell crab roll we had were excellent. The fish were super fresh, had the right amount of rice and it was nothing short of delicious. The braised black cod was excellent. Loved the presentation! It does get a tad bit salty because of all that ginger soy-reduction, but the fish just melts away in your mouthThe crispy Kombu brined chicken was delicious. The skin was extremely crispy, the chicken juicy. It's a pretty big portion size and quite filling.For desert we tried the warm chocolate cake with orange-sake sherbet. They added a nice candle and a happy b'day engraved chocolate piece to the dish. That was a nice touch! In terms of the taste, the cake was ok and I didn't care too much for the sherbet. Overall it was a lovely meal, pricey but worth it. Like i said if you are looking for a glamorous place with good ambiance and good food, this just has the latter. The staff is def. very helpful, attentive and the service rocks

Just had Morimoto's today for restaurant week and got the sushi whereas my friend ordered the cod. We also ordered the Toro tartare and sushi for one (not on RW menu). I have to say everything was good but not mind blowing. Adding on, I found that the sushi rice is harder than usual. Sushi was of high quality but did not taste fresh -- definitely had better else where. I would give this establishment 3.5 stars since things were either a hit or miss. Usually I would round up but for the price and the expectations, I'm a little bit disappointed.

The best dinning experience I've ever had. Impressive decor, sleek, creative, and minimalistic. Needless to say the food was masterfully prepared and presented. Foie Gras infused tofu pudding, spicy king crab legs, unique toro appetizer, and the sushi was to die for. Haven't found any other Japanese restaurant to match this one, not even Nobu in Beverly Hills, or the other Morimoto in Napa.I'll have to come here every time I'm in town now!

I have never been so disappointed by a highly rated restaurant as I was by morimoto. The interior decorations are chic,  modern, and gorgeous and I loved the atmosphere. However the food was subpar. I ordered sushi and I could have gotten better prepared sushi at ShopRite. Overpriced for the quality of food. You're basically paying for the ambience. Service was okay but not memorable. Not really Japanese food, more like American food using Japanese ingredients. Don't understand what all the hype is about. For good Japanese food go to Brushstroke or Kajitsu. This place tries too hard to be over the top.

By far my favorite Japanese restaurant in NYC. Everything is fresh and high quality. I can't say what I like the most specifically because everything in there is amazing. The atmosphere and seating is comfortable as well. Sometimes, if you notice hard enough, you'll see Morimoto around - met him twice. Doesn't speak much English, but very friendly fella.

I thought this place would serve great sushi after looking at the number of reviews and consistent and rating it received! I was mistaken. The sushi was below par compared to the high price I payed, $300 for two people. Honestly I've been other places where the sushi is better and cheaper. Overall I am disappointed.

Came here for my 23rd birthday and had high expectations for this place after having read the reviews. This place has pretty standard tasting food-- really not worth the price! Yes it's a trendy place but food was below par and we spent well over $300 for two people for seasonal sushi that, well, did not taste that fresh or flavorful. Disappointing, have had much better sushi!

My son was really looking forward to eating there. He was in the army and we have been planning this trip for 7 years until he got out.First off, we arrived at lunch. The hostess didn't greet us, just asked for our coats,then showed us to a table. Didn't smile, didn't even ask how our day was. I know shecould talk, because she spoke to others.The wait staff was uninterested in telling us about what was on the menu. They came across like it was a hardship for them.I wanted to try the Wagyu steak. Being from Nebraska, I know what good steak tasted like. Nobody can tell me that the steak I had was anything other than a good American steak. I won't ever believe that I got Wagyu.  Also, one comment. The restrooms were beautiful, but, for a person of an older age, the doors were very hard to push open and close. Maybe some grease?
Food was amazing, ambiance  was very nice. Kind of pricey but worth it. Will definitely  go back!

we thoroughly enjoyed our entire meal however the service was very slow and despite asking twice one of our appetizers was never brought out (thankfully it wasn't on the bill either).Despite some bumps in service, our waitress was very energetic and helpful. We'd go back.
Very good atmosphere, nice decorations, fancy place, food is delicious but pricey. Be ready to spend money.

I went to Morimoto today for an anniversary date with my girlfriend, and I must say I am more than impressed. I was so impressed by how fresh their menu was in itself to begin with, but their more-than attentive service made my experiences there even better....not to mention the ambiance. We had the miso glazed bone marrow and fresh oysters as appetizers. Both were unexpectedly unique...adding twists to well known appetizer items.Main course consisted of sushi/sashimi combos. The fish literally melts in your mouth. It's that fresh and high in quality.We were full from the food already, but our server surprised us with a well decorated yogurt mixed with berries for dessert. It had "Happy Anniversary" written in chocolate...and it literally made my gf cry. We were touched by their simple and genuine attention to detail. The manager even came out personally to greet and congratulate us, which was pretty cool. It was a fine conclusion for our dinner.

Wow that was good!  We needed to try a little bit of everything, since it was the great Iron Chef!  The appetizer, yellow tail done with pastrami spices, was so fresh and delicious, I ended up craving Pastrami all weekend.  Our sushi was made right in front of us; we specifically got a seat at the bar, and it was a lot of fun.  Sushi at Morimoto is just a given to be delicious.  Don't over-analyze, just be happy and enjoy it.  For the main course, we had duck.  The dipping sauces, including the duck egg, were fantastic.  The duck was cooked exquisitely, especially the crispy skin. We walked out too full for dessert, but quite pleased with the experience.  The only down side was the fish and rice dish that we ordered (it was just mediocre), but that might be more to what the dish was, than the way it was prepared... so we didn't let it take away from the evening.Great staff, very nice people there - held our reservation for a bit longer than normal to help us out of our traffic jam issues!

Dont get me wrong, I'm a big big fan of Morimoto. I try to go to all his restaurants when we travel but this experience was just a bad one. We walked there from the subway, as we came from out of town, with my back pack and stuff in street clothes. People were way too snobbish and judgemental. Made for a really expensive unhappy experience. It was like we were being rushed out of the restaurant. It seems as if youre not dressed to impress, youre not welcome. We ordered duck duck duck, angry chicken, kakuni congee, and spicy salmon sushi roll. Food was good. Experience, not so muchNo thank you;The philadelphia restaurant is way more personable. Another thing: the toilets are pretty impressive.

what can I say? it is Morimoto Came here for their lunch restaurant week. I got the black cod bento box and it was delicious! the cod literally melts in your mouth the second you put it in. The sushi was also very fresh. Service was excellent and the ambiance is hip and trendy The cocktail, White Lily was so yummy..at $14 dollars each...ouch and you MUST check out the bathroom when you come here...automatic toilets that cleans you..very cool will return again for sure!

Morimoto was definitely on my list of must trys during my first trip to New York.  Who doesn't love Iron Chef Morimoto?!?His restaurant is located in the MeatPacking District in New York.  We took a cab ride to the restaurant not too far away from our hotel.  The entrance was hidden behind huge red curtains.  As we passed through the red curtains, we found our way into the restaurant by a sliding door.  Right away we were greeted with the hostess to our right.  Straight ahead was a wall of lights that leads to the bar area downstairs.  Beautiful decor, beautiful lighting, great service, and very friendly staff.We were seated to a pretty small table for 2.  Didn't bother us at all.  Our waiter was extremely nice; she made many recommendations for food orders and drinks that turned out amazing!Here comes the food:1.  Toro Tartare: OF COURSE WE GOT THIS!! It was featured on FOODNETWORK: THE BEST THING I EVER ATE. As Duff from Aces of Cakes said during the show, who in his right mind would take Fatty Toro and mince it all up??!!! Are you serious?! Chef Morimoto does! I mean DELICIOUS!!! The side garnishes really make this dish so fun and innovative! From the Raw Bar:-Spicy King Crab : Delicious; the spicy cream sauce was a perfect match with the sweetness of the king crab.-Kumamoto Oysters: LOVE this as well; it was presented laying delicately on top of a huge bowl of ice.  Served perfectly chilled. Definitely a different texture compared to the oysters we have here in NOLA.We really don't like all the sauces and creams that most sushi rolls are done these days.  Nothing fancy..nothing fried..not covered all in mayo cream sauce.  We just like simplicity...just to taste the fish itself.  So we decided to go with the Chef's combination of sashimis and sushi.-Chef's Combinaton: of sushi, sushi rolls, and sashimi.  there's a 30, 50, 75, and up options.  I believe we picked the $50 option.  It was excellent.  Fish was very fresh.  Wouldn't expect anything less here.For an entree:1.) Ishi Yaki Bop: OMG. This was awesome! The Ishi Bop was prepared right at the table.  The rice was served in a HOT stone bowl.  There were pieces of that burned crisp rice you get when you cook rice over a flame WHICH I ABSOLUTELY LOVED!!! I use to scrap all the crunchy burnt rice when my grandmother use to cook her rice over open fire.  This dish definitely brought a very fond childhood memory for me.I cannot remember what we had for dessert for the life of me.  But overall Morimoto is a MUST TRY! The Toro Tartare ALONE keeps me dreaming and dreaming...ahhhh....i love NY!

I think I finally hit all the Morimoto's and none of them disappointed. Menus are basically the same and maybe they'll switch a thing or two depending on what city you're in. However, I took off 2 stars because we were going to do the Omakase for 3 people at ($125 per person) but the host said we couldn't but we were still allowed to order other things on the menu that was basically what was going to be in the Omakase palette. We had a late reservation but the restaurant was closing in 2 hours. So, what was the reason...? Because of that our bill came out to be $800 for 3 people with 1 small sake bottle and shit service. What the hell.....Do I get a personal chef to take back home with me too for that much?

Disappointing.  I guess I expected too much? But is it wrong of me to? Considering this is a very pricey place with a lot of recognition.  The best way to describe my reaction to this place is this smiley face  : | Obviously it can't be disgusting, its Morimoto.  But at the same time it wasn't good either.  The food is what I want to focus on because all the money in the world can create a beautiful restaurant and a fabulous staff.  The problem that I had with the food was that it was masked with flowers and cool plating and fancy things.  Close your eyes and eat their food next time and you'll realize that its just mediocre.  I love a beautiful dish, don't get me wrong, but only if its as equally as beautiful, chomped up in my mouth as well.  The most disappointing thing however, was something so basic, the rice.  Honestly, I've had better plain white rice at the local $6.95 General Tso take out restaurant.  It was dry, hard.... just terrible.  I am 100% positive that if Morimoto himself were to try this rice that I had he would shake his head.  Maybe it was a bad night? But the sushi rice was like that as well and honestly a bad night is a bad excuse for any Japanese restaurant, their rice should always be good.  I've skimmed through a lot of these reviews and yes, this place is stunning, yes you feel like a million bucks, yes the bathroom turns urinating into a whole new experience but focus people! The food! Imagine eating this food on your couch watching Teen Moms.  Would it be delicious then?

I may not be the target audience for this restaurant. I probably also made a mistake just ordering simple Nigiri and Sashimi here. I also ordered two appetizers, the Hamachi Tartare and the Oyster Foie Gras. Both were pretty good, but nothing to come back for. Don't get me wrong. There was absolutely nothing wrong with the food, but I guess I prefer my Sushi at a regular Sushi bar.The service was mixed. Our waitress was very friendly and helpful, but early on I received a cocktail that had nothing to do with what I ordered and ended up arguing with one of their guys about the ingredients: "A Sazerac is just an Old Fashioned but with Liqueur, right?". Erm no. Try again. Maybe I just came here on an off-night. Who knows. I may try again in the future.
Amazing food, excellent service, and great ambience. A very fine fusion of modern and traditional. The bathroom (as many people here have pointed out) is a cool easter egg.

5 * for sure. I booked this place for my one year anniversary with a lovely little lady. Booked through open table weeks in advance since we were visiting from California. A friend recommended this place because she had tried the one in Philly. But this one is the one... the Iron Chef Morimoto himself was there the night we booked.Atmosphere: Fantastic design, from the curtain ceilings to the light piece in the middle, to the slide door restrooms. Very modern and simple. Nice lighting for a romantic night or a close dinner with family/friends.Service: Friendly staff that was more than informative and knowledgeable. I believe it was the GM that came out to greet us and asked if we needed anything else on top. After each course, the table was touched up and ready for the next.Food: I tried the Omikase (chef's tasting) which was highly recommended from the Yelp reviews. This was a 7 course, starting off with toro tartare, then a sashmi carpaccio, followed by oyster with foie gras and uni, an anchovies fondue with veggies, then a nigri plate, main course was a lobster in curry with a sourcream lime sauce?, and wagyu beef on top of sweet potatoes. Desert with mango mousse with passion fruit puree. I normally skip deserts but this one got me wanting more. Each course was made with perfection and came with a drink or a japanese fruit to help clean the taste for the next.I am for sure coming back next time, maybe ordering individually to try the other selections. But this is a MUST if you are in NYC.On top... located near Highline. A park on top of buildings which is perfect for a stroll after dinner, before hitting up any lounges.

O em Geee best sushi rolls in town. I've had the shrimp avocado roll. Totally loved it, great texture and taste. For entrée I had duck, duck and duck. Of course I didnt have the poached egg. But the peking duck was good and the duck croissant was the best part of the meal. Portion was generous. My friend had the sea bass which I tried was really delish. As for dessert we had the mori-monkey bread  portion was again generous and we really enjoyed it.  Ambience was really chic I fell in love wit the decor. They had regular tables as well as a small lounge apart from the bar. Would love to take my hubby there on a date :)

The atmosphere was modern and clean. Server was very knowledgable of the menu and helpful in decision making. The sushi was delicious and melts in your mouth! Overall, the experience was wonderful and I would highly recommend this restaurant!

*GASP* how did I forget to write a review for Morimoto?! My friend and I came here during restaurant week last summer. We both got the black cod bento box, which came with: salad, tempura, miso soup, black cod, sushi and sashimi, and cocounut and green tea panna cotta.The presentation for all the dishes was excellent, and of course, everything tasted as good as it looked. The sauce that came with the tempura was simply outstanding. I vaguely remember it having a hint of cream cheese or sour cream. I couldn't quite put my finger on what it was, but my taste buds were loving it. The black cod-OH MY GOD. The flavors were just amazing. It definitely was the star of the meal. The sauce had a sweet kick to it, but not overly sweet. The texture was perfection.My favorite part was definitely the panna cotta. Coconut and green tea - these flavors work so wonderfully well together. Light, sweet, creamy, and delicious; it was the perfect way to end the meal. I would go back just to have that panna cotta. The service was outstanding. Oh, and make sure you check out the bathroom; it's definitely worth a visit!

I finally ate at Morimotos!!  I've been wanting to go to Morimotos for such a long time to try their omikase that I've heard so much about.  My husband brought me for a late birthday dinner.  The service was impeccable, the decor was trendy, and the food was delicious.  The dinner was expensive but you get what you pay for.  There were 1 or 2 things that I wasn't crazy about but the entree was top quality.  Overall, I am definitely a fan and I would go back there anytime.

Hydrangea drink. Everything! Fresh juices no syrups! The bone marrow appetizer awesome! The ribeye amazing! The ambiance and the service are excellent . If you want to add truffles to your meat or the beef carpaccio it's about 20 dollars per gram. Get the truffles! If you are the type to worry about the price, this place is not for you

Apparently I eat here often, yet I've never written a review.Morimoto has become the go-to place for lunch/dinners at my office. I prefer lunch here as it's fairly quiet (except during Restaurant Week). Sometimes you can have the whole sushi bar to yourself.Here are the stars in my book.For appetizers, the pork shumai, the rock shrimp, and the king crab. For lunch, I am a fan of the eel/foie gras bop (especially on a wintery day). They also do a ramen that is pretty great. The chirashi is a great lunch as well.They do the regular sushi/sashimi offerings and always have seasonal options. Of course, there are popular rolls as well.The sushi is good, but I don't go out of my way for it.The space is pretty awesome and they have a bar downstairs that is often the perfect after work spot if you can get there on a non-busy night.Oh, their wine list is great. A number of Champagnes and sushi-friendly white wines.My big complaint? Those plastic chopsticks. Yes, they look cool, but only when they are new. Some are looking scuffed. The other issue with them is that since they are plastic, you don't have that nice grippy quality you get with wood. Picking up large slices of slippery sashimi with them can be tricky.

Came here for a company dinner and I must say I was pretty disappointed. What I loved: White lily - shirayuri cocktail, Cheesecake soufflé with sorbet and fresh berries, Crispy Rock Shrimp Tempura (the wasabi one!), Spicy King Crab,  andthe fancy Japanese toilets with like 10 buttons! lolWhat I hated: Warm Flourless Chocolate Cake (nearly choked me to death. too dry)  Honorable Mentions: Tuna Pizza Tartare, the Cod Won't be returning.

Creative... but tasty? Even if the food wasn't so ridiculously expensive I've had much better food at less "prestigious" restaurants. Cool ambiance. Pretty good service. It was fine but probably won't go back.

Beautiful restrooms, attentive waitstaff, and delicious cocktails (get the ones that have yuzu in them- the citrusy tang is a nice compliment to the hard liquor).  The sushi and sashimi here are fresh and the selection is varied. Omakase for the win, as with most sushi spots in NYC.

LOVED our meal here. My husband and I came here to celebrate my mother's birthday dinner with a few of her friends.  Hung out downstairs while the rest of our party arrive (mother's friends got lost - so we drank cocktails and beers while waiting).  Downstairs bar is really cool. Restaurant is very modern inside.
